     Let θ₁ and θ₂ be the volumetric water contents at the two ends of an interval, and let Δh be the “thickness” of that tension interval. Then the water stored in that interval (per unit horizontal area) is approximately  
       (average θ) × Δh = (θ₁ + θ₂)/2 × Δh.  

     Using the table:

       ─ Interval 0–20:    θ averages (52 + 52)/2 = 52%,   storage = 0.52 × 20 = 10.4 cm  
       ─ Interval 20–40:   θ averages (52 + 50)/2 = 51%,   storage = 0.51 × 20 = 10.2 cm  
       ─ Interval 40–60:   θ averages (50 + 46.6)/2 = 48.3%, storage = 0.483 × 20 = 9.66 cm  
       ─ Interval 60–80:   θ averages (46.6 + 41.2)/2 = 43.9%, storage = 0.439 × 20 = 8.78 cm  
       ─ Interval 80–100:  θ averages (41.2 + 32)/2 = 36.6%,  storage = 0.366 × 20 = 7.32 cm  
       ─ Interval 100–120: θ averages (32 + 28)/2 = 30%,     storage = 0.30 × 20 = 6.00 cm  
       ─ Interval 120–137: θ averages (28 + 26)/2 = 27%,     storage = 0.27 × 17 = 4.59 cm  
       ─ Interval 137–150: θ averages (26 + 25)/2 = 25.5%,   storage = 0.255 × 13 = 3.315 cm  
       ─ Interval 150–170: θ averages (25 + 25)/2 = 25%,     storage = 0.25 × 20 = 5.00 cm  

     Summing those gives the water in the top 170 cm (above the initial water table):  
       10.4 + 10.2 + 9.66 + 8.78 + 7.32 + 6.00 + 4.59 + 3.315 + 5.00  
       = 65.265 cm of water.  

   – From 170 to 220 cm (i.e., below the initial water table):  
     This 50 cm layer was saturated when the water table was at 170 cm, so θ = 52%. Hence:  
       water stored = 0.52 × 50 cm = 26.0 cm.  

   – Total water storage in 0–220 cm, old scenario:  
     65.265 cm + 26.0 cm = 91.265 cm.  

3) Water stored after the drop (new scenario).  
   Now the water table has moved down to 220 cm below the surface. The entire 0–220 cm is above the new water table, so the tension ranges from 0 cm at 220 cm depth up to 220 cm at the surface. We again integrate (sum) the “average θ×thickness” from tension = 0 up to tension = 220.  

   – From tension 0 to 170 (the same intervals as before), we use the same stepwise calculation as above, which gave 65.265 cm of water, since θ depends only on tension.  
   – From tension 170 to 220 (an additional 50 cm of tension): the table shows θ = 25% by 170 cm tension, and we assume it remains 25% for tensions ≥ 170. Thus:  
       water stored in (170–220) = 0.25 × 50 cm = 12.5 cm.  

   – Total water storage in 0–220 cm, new scenario:  
       65.265 cm + 12.5 cm = 77.765 cm.  

4) Water drained.  
   The difference between the old and new total storage (over the same 0–220 cm profile) is the water drained from the soil:  
   91.265 cm (old) – 77.765 cm (new) = 13.5 cm of water.  

   Interpreted per unit horizontal area, 13.5 cm of water (i.e., 0.135 m of water) has drained out of the soil profile due to the water‐table drop from 170 cm to 220 cm.

Final result:  
\[
\boxed{13.5\text{ cm of water drained (per unit area).}}
\]

question:
The capillary pressure heads and volumetric moisture contents for a soil sample are listed below. Initially, the water table is at 280 cm. If it is reduced by 20 cm, calculate the volume of water released per unit area.

| Capillary pressure, cm | 0 | 20 | 50 | 80 | 100 | 120 | 150 | 170 | 200 | 230 | 250 | 280 |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| Volumetric moisture content, \% | 44 | 44 | 43 | 40.5 | 38 | 35 | 30 | 27 | 22 | 18 | 15.5 | 14 |
response:
First, note that the table gives us the equilibrium (capillary‐pressure‐dependent) volumetric moisture content, θ(h), for a soil profile.  Initially the water table is at h = 0 cm at the bottom of the profile and extends up to h = 280 cm at the top.  Lowering the water table by 20 cm effectively shifts every capillary pressure by +20 cm.  

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
STEP-BY-STEP OUTLINE
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

1) Discretize the 0–280 cm domain into intervals according to the table:  
   • 0–20 cm  
   • 20–50 cm  
   • 50–80 cm  
   • 80–100 cm  
   • 100–120 cm  
   • 120–150 cm  
   • 150–170 cm  
   • 170–200 cm  
   • 200–230 cm  
   • 230–250 cm  
   • 250–280 cm  

   For each interval, use the tabulated volumetric moisture content (in % or as a decimal) as representative (or average) over that interval.

2) Old (initial) moisture content in each interval.  
   From the table, convert % to decimal (e.g., 44 % → 0.44):

   ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
   Interval (cm)   Thickness   Old θ (decimal)
   ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
   0–20            20          0.44
   20–50           30          0.43
   50–80           30          0.405
   80–100          20          0.38
   100–120         20          0.35
   120–150         30          0.30
   150–170         20          0.27
   170–200         30          0.22
   200–230         30          0.18
   230–250         20          0.155
   250–280         30          0.14
   ----------------------------------------------------------------------------

3) New moisture content after lowering the water table 20 cm.  
   • A point originally at capillary pressure h now “sees” h + 20 cm in the new equilibrium.  
   • One may determine θ(h+20) piecewise by seeing which interval (of the original table) the new pressure (h+20) falls into.  

   Working interval by interval (shifting each old layer’s pressure by +20 cm):

   i)  0–20 cm old → corresponds to capillary pressures 20–40 cm new ⇒ ∼ 0.43  
   ii) 20–50 cm old → pressures 40–70 cm new → partly in 20–50 cm range (θ=0.43) and partly in 50–80 cm range (θ=0.405). A weighted average over 40–50 cm (10 cm) and 50–70 cm (20 cm) gives  
       new θ = [ (10×0.43) + (20×0.405 ) ] / 30 = 0.4133.  
   iii) 50–80 cm old → pressures 70–100 cm new → partly in 50–80 cm (θ=0.405) and 80–100 cm (θ=0.38). Weighted average (10 cm at 0.405, 20 cm at 0.38) gives 0.3883.  
   iv) 80–100 cm old → 100–120 cm new ⇒ θ=0.35.  
   v)  100–120 cm old → 120–140 cm new ⇒ entirely in 120–150 cm range ⇒ θ=0.30.  
   vi) 120–150 cm old → 140–170 cm new ⇒ partly 140–150 cm (θ=0.30) and 150–170 cm (θ=0.27) ⇒ weighted average = 0.28.  
   vii)150–170 cm old → 170–190 cm new ⇒ (170–200 cm range in the table is θ=0.22) for at least 20 cm, so θ=0.22.  
   viii)170–200 cm old → 190–220 cm new ⇒ partly 170–200 cm (θ=0.22) for 10 cm and 200–230 cm (θ=0.18) for 20 cm ⇒ weighted average = 0.1933.  
   ix) 200–230 cm old → 220–250 cm new ⇒ 220–230 cm (θ=0.18) for 10 cm, 230–250 cm (θ=0.155) for 20 cm ⇒ average = 0.1633.  
   x)  230–250 cm old → 250–270 cm new ⇒ 250–280 cm range gives θ=0.14 (for that 20 cm segment).  
   xi) 250–280 cm old → 270–300 cm new ⇒ the table ends at 280 cm (θ=0.14). Often one assumes the same trend continues (slightly decreasing).  A simpler (common) approximation is to keep θ=0.14.  

   Hence the new θ values (approx):

   ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
   Interval   Old thickness   Old θ     New θ 
   ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
   0–20       20             0.44      0.43
   20–50      30             0.43      0.4133
   50–80      30             0.405     0.3883
   80–100     20             0.38      0.35
   100–120    20             0.35      0.30
   120–150    30             0.30      0.28
   150–170    20             0.27      0.22
   170–200    30             0.22      0.1933
   200–230    30             0.18      0.1633
   230–250    20             0.155     0.14
   250–280    30             0.14      0.14  (no change assumed)
   ----------------------------------------------------------------------------

4) Water released in each interval = (Old θ − New θ) × (thickness).  
   Converting θ to decimals, the thickness in cm yields cm of water per unit area:

   1)  (0.44 − 0.43) × 20 cm  = 0.01 × 20  = 0.20  
   2)  (0.43 − 0.4133) × 30 cm  = 0.0167 × 30  = 0.50  
   3)  (0.405 − 0.3883) × 30 cm  = 0.0167 × 30  = 0.50  
   4)  (0.38 − 0.35) × 20 cm  = 0.03 × 20   = 0.60  
   5)  (0.35 − 0.30) × 20 cm  = 0.05 × 20   = 1.00  
   6)  (0.30 − 0.28) × 30 cm  = 0.02 × 30   = 0.60  
   7)  (0.27 − 0.22) × 20 cm  = 0.05 × 20   = 1.00  
   8)  (0.22 − 0.1933) × 30 cm  = 0.0267 × 30 = 0.80  
   9)  (0.18 − 0.1633) × 30 cm  = 0.0167 × 30 = 0.50  
   10) (0.155 − 0.14) × 20 cm  = 0.015 × 20  = 0.30  
   11) (0.14 − 0.14) × 30 cm   = 0          = 0.00  

   Summing these:

   0.20 + 0.50 + 0.50 + 0.60 + 1.00 + 0.60 + 1.00 + 0.80 + 0.50 + 0.30 + 0.00  
   = 6.00 cm of water (approximately)

Thus, about 6 cm of water (per unit horizontal area) drain out of the soil when the water table is lowered by 20 cm.

\[
\boxed{6\text{ cm of water per unit area}}
\]

question:
A $100-\mathrm{g}$ sample of dry soil is analyzed for moisture distribution due to capillary action. The variations in negative pressure head and the corresponding amounts of water released from the sample are detailed below. The soil's bulk density is $1.4 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cc}$, and when saturated, it contains $38 \%$ moisture by weight.

| Negative Pressure Head (cm) | Water Released ( $\mathrm{cm}^{3}$ ) |
| :--- | :--- |
| 0 | 0.0 |
| 10 | 0.2 |
| 20 | 0.3 |
| 30 | 0.6 |
| 40 | 0.9 |
| 50 | 1.3 |
| 60 | 1.7 |
| 70 | 1.4 |
| 80 | 0.8 |
| 90 | 0.4 |
| 100 | 0.2 |

(a). Determine the volumetric moisture content for each pressure head (the ratio of the volume of water retained to the volume of soil). 
(b). Create a graph of the moisture distribution curve.
(c). Calculate the amount of water drained from the soil if the water table decreases from 100 cm to 150 cm below the surface. 
(d). What is the soil's porosity?
(e). Determine the soil's specific retention.
(f). Calculate the soil's specific yield.
response:
Solution Explanation (step by step)

We have the following data about a 100 g dry‐soil sample:

• Bulk density of the soil, ρ_b = 1.4 g cm⁻³.  
• At saturation, the soil contains 38 % moisture by weight.  
• Hence, for 100 g of dry soil, the mass of water at saturation is 38 g of water (≈ 38 cm³).  
• The total (bulk) volume of the 100 g sample is  
  V_soil = (mass of dry soil) / (bulk density) = 100 g / (1.4 g cm⁻³) ≈ 71.4 cm³.  

Thus, at h = 0 cm (zero suction, i.e., fully saturated), the sample holds 38 cm³ of water in a total soil volume of 71.4 cm³.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
a) Volumetric moisture content for each pressure head
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

From the table, the numbers given under “Water Released (cm³)” are the incremental amounts of water that drain out as the negative pressure head (suction) increases by 10 cm each step.  First, convert those incremental releases into a cumulative release up to each suction value.  Let W(h) = total water drained (cumulatively) by the time the suction is h.  Then the water still in the sample at suction h is

  W_ret(h) = (water at saturation) − W(h).

Below is the running total W(h), followed by the retained water W_ret(h), and finally the volumetric moisture content θ(h) = W_ret(h) / V_soil:

1) Compute cumulative water released W(h):
   • h = 0 cm:  W(0) = 0.0 cm³.  
   • h = 10 cm: W(10) = 0.2 cm³.  
   • h = 20 cm: W(20) = 0.2 + 0.3 = 0.5 cm³.  
   • h = 30 cm: W(30) = 0.5 + 0.6 = 1.1 cm³.  
   • h = 40 cm: W(40) = 1.1 + 0.9 = 2.0 cm³.  
   • h = 50 cm: W(50) = 2.0 + 1.3 = 3.3 cm³.  
   • h = 60 cm: W(60) = 3.3 + 1.7 = 5.0 cm³.  
   • h = 70 cm: W(70) = 5.0 + 1.4 = 6.4 cm³.  
   • h = 80 cm: W(80) = 6.4 + 0.8 = 7.2 cm³.  
   • h = 90 cm: W(90) = 7.2 + 0.4 = 7.6 cm³.  
   • h = 100 cm: W(100) = 7.6 + 0.2 = 7.8 cm³.

2) Water retained at each suction:
   W_ret(h) = 38 cm³ − W(h).

3) Volumetric moisture content:
   θ(h) = W_ret(h) / 71.4 cm³.

Hence the table of volumetric moisture contents is:

• h = 0 cm:   W_ret = 38.0,  θ = 38.0 / 71.4 ≈ 0.532  
• h = 10 cm:  W_ret = 37.8,  θ = 37.8 / 71.4 ≈ 0.529  
• h = 20 cm:  W_ret = 37.5,  θ = 37.5 / 71.4 ≈ 0.525  
• h = 30 cm:  W_ret = 36.9,  θ = 36.9 / 71.4 ≈ 0.517  
• h = 40 cm:  W_ret = 36.0,  θ = 36.0 / 71.4 ≈ 0.505  
• h = 50 cm:  W_ret = 34.7,  θ = 34.7 / 71.4 ≈ 0.486  
• h = 60 cm:  W_ret = 33.0,  θ = 33.0 / 71.4 ≈ 0.462  
• h = 70 cm:  W_ret = 31.6,  θ = 31.6 / 71.4 ≈ 0.443  
• h = 80 cm:  W_ret = 30.8,  θ = 30.8 / 71.4 ≈ 0.431  
• h = 90 cm:  W_ret = 30.4,  θ = 30.4 / 71.4 ≈ 0.426  
• h = 100 cm: W_ret = 30.2,  θ = 30.2 / 71.4 ≈ 0.423  

Answer for part (a):
\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\theta(0\text{ cm}) &\approx 0.532,\\
\theta(10\text{ cm}) &\approx 0.529,\\
\theta(20\text{ cm}) &\approx 0.525,\\
\theta(30\text{ cm}) &\approx 0.517,\\
\theta(40\text{ cm}) &\approx 0.505,\\
\theta(50\text{ cm}) &\approx 0.486,\\
\theta(60\text{ cm}) &\approx 0.462,\\
\theta(70\text{ cm}) &\approx 0.443,\\
\theta(80\text{ cm}) &\approx 0.431,\\
\theta(90\text{ cm}) &\approx 0.426,\\
\theta(100\text{ cm}) &\approx 0.423.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
b) Graph of the moisture distribution curve
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

You would plot the negative pressure head h (cm) on the horizontal axis and the corresponding θ(h) on the vertical axis.  It typically has the shape of a decreasing function: high moisture content at low suction (near saturation), and lower moisture content as suction increases.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
c) Amount of water drained if the water table decreases from 100 cm to 150 cm
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Strictly, the table only gives data up to h = 100 cm.  One must either (i) extrapolate the curve to h = 150 cm, or (ii) estimate from the incremental releases.  

Because the increments from 90→100 cm were only 0.2 cm³, the release rate is clearly diminishing at larger suction.  A rough linear or exponential extrapolation suggests that moving from 100 cm to 150 cm of suction likely drains on the order of 0.2 – 0.3 cm³ of additional water from the 100 g sample.  

For a simple estimate (often used in classroom examples), one might take the last observed increment (0.2 cm³ per 10 cm of suction) and assume it halves or otherwise diminishes for each further 10 cm.  A reasonable ballpark is about 0.2 cm³ total.  

Thus, the amount of water drained for h going from 100 cm to 150 cm is approximately:

\[
\boxed{0.2\text{ cm}^3 \text{ (for the 100 g sample).}}
\]

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
d) Soil’s porosity
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Porosity ϕ is the ratio of total pore volume to the bulk volume of soil.  When the sample is fully saturated (h = 0), its volumetric moisture content equals the porosity (since all pores are filled with water).  From part (a) at h = 0 cm, we found

  θ_sat = 38 cm³ / 71.4 cm³ ≈ 0.532.

Hence,
\[
\boxed{\text{Porosity } \phi \approx 0.532 \text{ (i.e., }53.2\%\text{).}}
\]

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
e) Soil’s specific retention
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

By definition in groundwater hydrology, the specific retention S_r is the fraction of the total volume that remains in the soil after it is drained by gravity.  Although there is some variability in how “after gravity drainage” is defined, a common simplifying assumption (especially if only given data to 100 cm tension) is to take the volumetric water content at a reasonably large tension (e.g., 100 cm) as the retained water.

From part (a), at h = 100 cm:

  θ(100 cm) ≈ 0.423.

Thus the soil’s specific retention is about 0.423:

\[
\boxed{\text{Specific retention } S_r \approx 0.423.}
\]

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
f) Soil’s specific yield
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

The specific yield S_y is the fraction of the total volume of the soil that will drain under gravity from saturation down to the chosen “gravity‐drained” condition.  Equivalently,

  S_y = ϕ − S_r,

where ϕ is the porosity (from part d) and S_r is the specific retention (from part e).  Hence,

  S_y = 0.532 − 0.423 = 0.109.

As a percentage, that is about 10.9 %.

\[
\boxed{\text{Specific yield } S_y \approx 0.109.}
\]

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Summary of Results
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

a) See boxed table of θ(h).  
b) Plot h (cm) versus θ(h).  
c) Water drained from 100 cm to 150 cm suction ≈ 0.2 cm³ (for this 100 g sample).  
d) Porosity ϕ ≈ 0.532 (53.2 %).  
e) Specific retention S_r ≈ 0.423 (42.3 %).  
f) Specific yield S_y ≈ 0.109 (10.9 %).

question: In a clay-rich formation, the groundwater level decreases by 0.6 m across an 8-hectare area. Determine the volume of water that is removed if the specific yield is $23 \%$. $\left(1 \mathrm{~km}^{2}=100\right.$ hectares $)$
response:
Solution Explanation:

Step 1: Convert the area from hectares to square meters.  
• 1 hectare = 10,000 m²  
• Given area = 8 hectares ⇒ A = 8 × 10,000 = 80,000 m²  

Step 2: Express the specific yield as a decimal.  
• Specific yield = 23% = 0.23  

Step 3: Use the relation for the volume of water removed.  
Volume removed = Area × Decline in groundwater level × Specific yield  

Substitute the known values:  
V = 80,000 m² × 0.6 m × 0.23  

Step 4: Calculate the volume.  
First, multiply 80,000 m² and 0.6 m:  
  80,000 m² × 0.6 m = 48,000 m³  

Then multiply by 0.23:  
  48,000 m³ × 0.23 = 11,040 m³  

Hence, the volume of water removed is 11,040 m³.  

Final Answer:  
\[
\boxed{11,040 \text{ m}^3}
\]

question: The specific storage for an artesian aquifer is $1.2 \times 10^{-6}$ per ft, and its porosity is 0.35. Calculate the modulus of elasticity for the soil solids. What portion of the storage coefficient results from the expansion of water in the aquifer, and what portion is due to the compression of the aquifer itself? $\left(\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{W}}=3 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{psi}\right)$
response:
Solution Explanation:

We are given:

• Specific storage of the confined (artesian) aquifer:  
  Sₛ = 1.2 × 10⁻⁶ ft⁻¹  
• Porosity of the aquifer:  
  n = 0.35  
• Modulus of elasticity (bulk modulus) of water:  
  E_w = 3 × 10⁵ psi  

We wish to (1) find the modulus of elasticity of the soil solids, E_s, and (2) determine what fraction of the total Sₛ is contributed by expansion of water versus compression of the aquifer skeleton.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1) Relationship between specific storage and elastic moduli

A common (U.S. customary–units) expression for the specific storage Sₛ of a confined aquifer is:

Sₛ = γ_w [ (n / E_w) + (1 − n) / E_s ],

where  
• γ_w is the unit weight of water (≈ 62.4 lb/ft³),  
• E_w is the (bulk) modulus of elasticity of water (in lb/ft²),  
• E_s is the modulus of elasticity of the solid grains (in lb/ft²),  
• n is porosity,  
• Sₛ has units of 1/ft, provided E_w and E_s are also in lb/ft².

Since E_w is given in psi, we convert from psi to lb/ft² using 1 psi = 144 lb/ft². Thus,

E_w (in lb/ft²) = (3 × 10⁵ psi) × (144 lb/ft² per psi) = 4.32 × 10⁷ lb/ft².

Hence the compressibility of water is 1/E_w = 1 / (4.32 × 10⁷) = 2.31 × 10⁻⁸ (lb/ft²)⁻¹.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2) Contribution to Sₛ from water expansion alone

If we consider only water compressibility (and ignore skeleton compression), that portion is:

Sₛ,water = γ_w × n × (1/E_w)  
          = 62.4 × 0.35 × (1 / 4.32 × 10⁷).

Numerically,

• 1/E_w = 2.31 × 10⁻⁸ (lb/ft²)⁻¹  
• So n × (1/E_w) = 0.35 × 2.31 × 10⁻⁸ = 8.09 × 10⁻⁹ (lb/ft²)⁻¹  

Multiply by γ_w = 62.4 lb/ft³:

Sₛ,water = 62.4 × 8.09 × 10⁻⁹ ≈ 5.05 × 10⁻⁷ ft⁻¹.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3) Solving for the soil-solids modulus E_s

We know the total observed specific storage is:

Sₛ(total) = 1.2 × 10⁻⁶ ft⁻¹.

Hence the “skeleton” portion (a.k.a. aquifer-compression portion) is the remainder,

Sₛ,skeleton = 1.2 × 10⁻⁶ − 5.05 × 10⁻⁷ = 6.95 × 10⁻⁷ ft⁻¹.

But from the formula, that skeleton portion is also

Sₛ,skeleton = γ_w × (1 − n) × (1/E_s).

Thus,

6.95 × 10⁻⁷ = 62.4 × 0.65 × (1/E_s).

So

1/E_s = (6.95 × 10⁻⁷) / (62.4 × 0.65)  (lb/ft²)⁻¹.

Numerically, the denominator is 62.4 × 0.65 ≈ 40.56, so

1/E_s ≈ (6.95 × 10⁻⁷) / 40.56 ≈ 1.11 × 10⁻⁸ (lb/ft²)⁻¹,

⇒ E_s ≈ 1 / (1.11 × 10⁻⁸) ≈ 5.85 × 10⁷ lb/ft².

Finally, convert E_s to psi by dividing by 144:

E_s (in psi) = (5.85 × 10⁷) / 144 ≈ 4.06 × 10⁵ psi.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
4) Fraction of storage from water vs. skeleton

• Water contribution: 5.05 × 10⁻⁷ ft⁻¹  
• Skeleton contribution: 6.95 × 10⁻⁷ ft⁻¹  
• Total: 1.20 × 10⁻⁶ ft⁻¹

Thus,

– Fraction from water = (5.05 × 10⁻⁷) / (1.20 × 10⁻⁶) ≈ 42%.  
– Fraction from skeleton = (6.95 × 10⁻⁷) / (1.20 × 10⁻⁶) ≈ 58%.  

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Answer Formatting

a) Modulus of elasticity for the soil solids:

\[
\boxed{4.1\times 10^5 \text{ psi}}
\]

b) Of the total specific storage (1.2×10⁻⁶ ft⁻¹):

– About 42% arises from expansion of the water.  
– About 58% arises from compression of the aquifer skeleton.

Hence, in terms of Sₛ:
• Sₛ,water ≈ 5.0 × 10⁻⁷ ft⁻¹,  
• Sₛ,skeleton ≈ 7.0 × 10⁻⁷ ft⁻¹.  

\[
\boxed{\text{Water expansion } \approx 42\%,\quad \text{Aquifer compression } \approx 58\%.}
\]

question: Based on a pumping test conducted on a confined formation, the storage coefficient is determined to be $3 \times 10^{-3}$ at a site where the water depth is 50 m. For an aquifer covering an area of $3.2 \mathrm{~km}^{2}$ with an average depth of 35 m, calculate the volume of water released by the area when the pressure head decreases by 10 m.
response:
Step-by-step solution:

1) Recall that for a confined aquifer, the volume of water (ΔV) released (or taken into storage) when the piezometric head changes by an amount Δh is given by:  
   ΔV = S × A × Δh  
   where  
   • S is the storage coefficient (dimensionless),  
   • A is the area of the aquifer (m²),  
   • Δh is the change in head (m).

2) From the problem statement:  
   • S = 3 × 10⁻³,  
   • A = 3.2 km² = 3.2 × 10⁶ m²,  
   • Δh = 10 m.

3) Substitute these values into the formula:  
   ΔV = (3 × 10⁻³) × (3.2 × 10⁶ m²) × (10 m).

4) Compute step by step:  
   a) Multiply S by A:  
      (3 × 10⁻³) × (3.2 × 10⁶) = 9.6 × 10³.  
   b) Now multiply by Δh:  
      9.6 × 10³ × 10 = 9.6 × 10⁴ = 96,000 m³.

Hence, the volume of water released from the aquifer when the pressure head decreases by 10 m over the 3.2 km² area is  
\[
\boxed{9.6 \times 10^4 \text{ m}^3}.
\]

question: Consider a confined aquifer with an average thickness of 150 ft and a porosity of 0.35. Given that the compressibility of water is $3 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{in}^{2}{ }^{2} / \mathrm{lb}$ and the material compressibility is $2.5 \times 10^{-6}$ in. ${ }^{2} / \mathrm{lb}$, determine the storage coefficient of the aquifer.
response:
Solution Explanation (Step by Step):

We wish to find the storage coefficient S of a confined aquifer. In general, for a confined aquifer of thickness b, the storage coefficient is given by

S = S_s × b,

where S_s is the specific storage (in reciprocal length units) and b is the aquifer thickness (in length units).

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1) Specific Storage Formula

A common empirical expression for the specific storage S_s is:

S_s = γ [ n β_w + α_s ],

where
• γ is the unit weight of water (lb/in³ in this problem),
• n is the porosity,
• β_w is the compressibility of water (in²/lb),
• α_s is the “skeletal” or “matrix” compressibility (in²/lb).

Given values:  
• β_w = 3 × 10⁻⁶ in²/lb (compressibility of water),  
• α_s = 2.5 × 10⁻⁶ in²/lb (material/skeletal compressibility),  
• n = 0.35 (porosity),  
• b = 150 ft (aquifer thickness).  

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2) Convert Thickness to Inches

Because compressibilities are in in²/lb and γ is in lb/in³, convert b from feet to inches:

b = 150 ft × (12 in / 1 ft) = 1800 in.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3) Compute the Unit Weight of Water (γ)

In U.S. customary units, water has a weight density of about 62.4 lb/ft³. Converting to lb/in³:

γ = 62.4 (lb/ft³) ÷ 1728 (in³/ft³) ≈ 0.0361 lb/in³.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
4) Sum of Compressibilities

Inside the bracket (…), we have n β_w + α_s:

n β_w = 0.35 × (3 × 10⁻⁶ in²/lb) = 1.05 × 10⁻⁶ in²/lb,

So,

n β_w + α_s = 1.05 × 10⁻⁶ + 2.5 × 10⁻⁶ = 3.55 × 10⁻⁶ in²/lb.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
5) Calculate the Specific Storage S_s

S_s = γ × (n β_w + α_s)  
    = (0.0361 lb/in³) × (3.55 × 10⁻⁶ in²/lb).

Performing the multiplication:

3.55 × 10⁻⁶ × 0.0361 ≈ (3.55 × 0.0361) × 10⁻⁶  
                      ≈ 0.128 × 10⁻⁶  
                      = 1.28 × 10⁻⁷.

Hence,

S_s ≈ 1.28 × 10⁻⁷  (in⁻¹).

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
6) Multiply by the Aquifer Thickness b

Finally, multiply by b = 1800 in to get the storage coefficient S:

S = S_s × b  
  = (1.28 × 10⁻⁷ in⁻¹) × (1800 in)  
  = 1.28 × 1800 × 10⁻⁷  
  = 2.304 × 10⁻⁴.

Rounding slightly,

S ≈ 2.3 × 10⁻⁴.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Final Answer

\(\boxed{2.3 \times 10^{-4}}\)

question: A well with a radius of 6 inches is drilled into a confined aquifer that has a thickness of 100 feet. The aquifer is composed of uniform sand with an average grain size of 0.3 inches. The pumping rate of the well is $100 \mathrm{ft}^{3} / \mathrm{hr}$. Assess if Darcy's flow conditions are present near the well at a temperature of $60^{\circ} \mathrm{F}$.
response:
Solution Explanation:

We wish to check whether flow in the sand near the well satisfies Darcy’s law at 60 °F. A common way to assess the applicability of Darcy’s law is to estimate the porous‐media Reynolds number (sometimes called Re_d) and verify that it remains below about 1–10 in magnitude. The Reynolds number in a porous medium is (in SI units):

Re_d = (ρ v_i d) / μ,

where  
• ρ is the fluid density (kg m⁻³),  
• v_i is the interstitial (pore) velocity (m s⁻¹),  
• d is a characteristic pore diameter or representative grain diameter (m),  
• μ is the dynamic viscosity of the fluid (Pa s).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
STEP 1: Determine the volumetric flux (Darcy velocity) near the well
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
• Pumping rate, Q = 100 ft³/hr. Convert to ft³/s:  
  Q (ft³/s) = 100 (ft³/hr) × (1 hr / 3600 s) = 100/3600 ≈ 0.0278 ft³/s.

• Assume the entire screened interval is the perimeter of the well times the aquifer thickness.  
  – Well radius r = 6 in = 0.5 ft.  
  – Perimeter = 2πr ≈ 2π × 0.5 ft = π ft ≈ 3.14 ft.  
  – Aquifer thickness = 100 ft.  
  – Cross‐sectional (cylindrical) area through which flow enters = (perimeter) × (thickness) = 3.14 ft × 100 ft ≈ 314 ft².

• Darcy velocity (volumetric flux), v_D:  
  v_D = Q / (cross‐sectional area) = (0.0278 ft³/s) / (314 ft²) ≈ 8.84×10⁻⁵ ft/s.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
STEP 2: Compute the interstitial (pore) velocity
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Let n be the porosity of the sand. Typical porosity for uniform coarse sand could be around 0.30–0.40. Assume n ≈ 0.35 for estimation.  
The interstitial velocity v_i is the Darcy velocity divided by the porosity:  

v_i = v_D / n = (8.84×10⁻⁵ ft/s) / 0.35 ≈ 2.53×10⁻⁴ ft/s.

We next convert this to SI units to use standard ρ and μ values:  
• 1 ft = 0.3048 m, so  
  v_i ≈ 2.53×10⁻⁴ ft/s × 0.3048 (m/ft) ≈ 7.70×10⁻⁵ m/s.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
STEP 3: Convert grain size and retrieve fluid properties
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
• Grain size d = 0.3 in. Convert to meters:  
  d ≈ 0.3 in × 2.54 (cm/in) × 10⁻² (m/cm) = 0.0076 m.

• At ~60 °F, use approximations for water:  
  – ρ ≈ 1000 kg/m³,  
  – μ ≈ 1.14×10⁻³ Pa s.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
STEP 4: Calculate the Reynolds number in the porous medium
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Re_d = (ρ v_i d) / μ.

Putting in the values:  
ρ = 1000 kg/m³,  
v_i = 7.70×10⁻⁵ m/s,  
d = 0.0076 m,  
μ = 1.14×10⁻³ Pa s.

So,

Re_d = [1000 × (7.70×10⁻⁵) × (0.0076)] / (1.14×10⁻³)  
     ≈ (1000 × 5.85×10⁻⁷) / (1.14×10⁻³)  
     = 5.85×10⁻⁴ / 1.14×10⁻³  
     ≈ 0.51.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
STEP 5: Conclude whether Darcy’s law applies
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Because Re_d ≈ 0.51 < 1, the flow remains well within the laminar/creeping‐flow regime typically associated with Darcy’s law validity. Hence, we conclude that Darcy‐type flow conditions hold near the well at the given pumping rate.

∴ Darcy’s flow conditions are present near the well.

\boxed{\text{Yes, Darcy's flow conditions are satisfied, since } Re_d \approx 0.51 < 1.}

question:
A uniform, isotropic aquifer possesses a hydraulic conductivity of $0.02 \mathrm{ft} / \mathrm{s}$. The head gradients in the $x, y$, and $z$ directions are $0, 0.19$, and 0.87, respectively.  
a. Calculate the components of the velocity vector.  
b. Illustrate the velocity vectors for the aquifer.  
c. Determine the magnitude and direction of the aquifer's velocity.
response:
Solution Explanation:

We are given:

• A uniform, isotropic aquifer with hydraulic conductivity K = 0.02 ft/s.  
• The hydraulic head gradients are:  
  ∂h/∂x = 0,  
  ∂h/∂y = 0.19,  
  ∂h/∂z = 0.87.  

Recall that for an isotropic aquifer, Darcy’s law in three dimensions gives the (Darcy) velocity components as:  
vₓ = −K (∂h / ∂x),  
vᵧ = −K (∂h / ∂y),  
v𝓏 = −K (∂h / ∂z).  

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
a) Calculate the components of the velocity vector.

Using the values given:  

vₓ = −(0.02 ft/s)(0)    = 0 ft/s,  
vᵧ = −(0.02 ft/s)(0.19) = −0.0038 ft/s,  
v𝓏 = −(0.02 ft/s)(0.87) = −0.0174 ft/s.  

Hence, the velocity components are:  
a)  
\[
\boxed{v_x = 0,\quad v_y = -0.0038\,\text{ft/s},\quad v_z = -0.0174\,\text{ft/s}}
\]  

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
b) Illustrate the velocity vectors for the aquifer.

Since vₓ = 0, vᵧ < 0, and v𝓏 < 0, the flow is directed in the negative y-direction and negative z-direction. In a typical right-handed coordinate system where x is to the right, y is into the page, and z is upward, the velocity vector in the y–z plane points “downward and into” the page. 

A sketch (roughly) would show an arrow pointing negatively in both the y and z directions:

         z
         ↑
         |
         |
 (x out of page)   • (velocity arrow slanting “down & left”
         |
         |
         +---->  y (pointing here means negative y)

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
c) Determine the magnitude and direction of the aquifer’s velocity.

1) Magnitude  

The magnitude of the velocity vector is  
|v| = √(vₓ² + vᵧ² + v𝓏²)  
     = √(0² + (−0.0038)² + (−0.0174)²)  
     = √(1.444×10⁻⁵ + 3.0276×10⁻⁴)  
     ≈ √(3.172×10⁻⁴)  
     ≈ 0.0178 ft/s.  

2) Direction  

• In the horizontal plane, the velocity has no x-component, so it is entirely in the negative y direction.  
• Vertically, it has a negative z-component, indicating downward flow.  

Often one reports (i) an azimuth within the horizontal plane (270° from the +x axis, since it is along −y) and (ii) a dip angle downward from the horizontal plane. The dip angle θ from horizontal satisfies  
tan(θ) = (vertical component magnitude) / (horizontal component magnitude)  
        = (0.0174) / (0.0038)  
        ≈ 4.58,  
θ ≈ arctan(4.58) ≈ 77.7°.  

Hence the flow is about 77.7° below the horizontal toward negative y.

Therefore,  
c)  
\[
\boxed{\text{Magnitude: }|v|\approx 0.0178\,\text{ft/s},\quad
\text{Direction: }77.7^\circ\text{ downward from horizontal in the negative y-direction.}}
\]

question:
A uniform anisotropic aquifer is characterized by these gradients and hydraulic conductivities:

|  | $i$ | $K(\mathrm{ft} / \mathrm{min})$ |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| $x$ direction | 0 | 0.04 |
| $y$ direction | 0.15 | 0.042 |
| $z$ direction | 0.82 | 0.003 |

a. Determine the Darcy's velocity vector.
b. Illustrate the velocity potential vectors.
c. Evaluate the specific discharge.
response:
Solution Explanation:

We are told an aquifer is anisotropic (different hydraulic conductivity in each principal direction) with the following data:

• Hydraulic gradient (i) and hydraulic conductivity (K) in x-direction:  
  iₓ = 0,   Kₓ = 0.04 ft/min  
• Hydraulic gradient (i) and hydraulic conductivity (K) in y-direction:  
  iᵧ = 0.15,   Kᵧ = 0.042 ft/min  
• Hydraulic gradient (i) and hydraulic conductivity (K) in z-direction:  
  i_z = 0.82,   K_z = 0.003 ft/min  

Recall Darcy’s Law in tensor (anisotropic) form can be written (for principal axes aligned with x, y, z) as  
qₓ = -Kₓ iₓ,   qᵧ = -Kᵧ iᵧ,   q_z = -K_z i_z.  

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
a) Determine the Darcy’s velocity vector
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

1) In the x-direction:  
   qₓ = -Kₓ iₓ = -(0.04)(0) = 0.  

2) In the y-direction:  
   qᵧ = -Kᵧ iᵧ = -(0.042)(0.15) = -0.0063 ft/min.  

3) In the z-direction:  
   q_z = -K_z i_z = -(0.003)(0.82) = -0.00246 ft/min.  

Hence, the Darcy (specific discharge) velocity vector is  
q = ( 0,  -0.0063,  -0.00246 ) ft/min.  

Therefore,  
a) \(\boxed{\,q = \bigl(0,\,-0.0063,\,-0.00246\bigr)\ \text{ft/min}\!}\)

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
b) Illustrate the velocity potential vectors
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Conceptually, in isotropic media one often writes q = -K ∇h, so that equipotential surfaces are surfaces of constant head h, and flow (Darcy velocity) vectors point opposite to ∇h. In anisotropic media (with principal directions along x, y, z) the relation is:

q = - (Kₓ, Kᵧ, K_z) ⊗ ∇h,

where “⊗” indicates each directional gradient is scaled by the corresponding K. Here, our velocity vector is purely in y and z, since iₓ = 0 makes qₓ = 0. One way to “illustrate” or interpret a velocity potential for anisotropy is to note that q is constant in space under the uniform gradients given, and its direction is determined by the negative y and z gradients scaled by Kᵧ and K_z.

If one wished to define a “potential” Φ such that q = ∇Φ (sometimes called a velocity potential), a simple linear function Φ(x, y, z) whose partial derivatives match the components of q would be

∂Φ/∂x = 0,   ∂Φ/∂y = -0.0063,   ∂Φ/∂z = -0.00246,

leading to

Φ(x, y, z) = -0.0063 y - 0.00246 z + constant.

In vector form, the gradient of Φ is exactly (0, -0.0063, -0.00246). Thus the “velocity potential vector” field is constant in space, pointing in the negative y-z quadrant (no x-component).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
c) Evaluate the specific discharge
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Often “specific discharge” is synonymous with the Darcy velocity vector q. If only the magnitude is required:

|q| = √(qₓ² + qᵧ² + q_z²)  
     = √(0² + (-0.0063)² + (-0.00246)²)  
     = √(3.969 × 10⁻⁵ + 6.0516 × 10⁻⁶)  
     = √(4.57416 × 10⁻⁵)  
     ≈ 0.00677 ft/min.

Thus, the magnitude of the specific discharge is about 0.00677 ft/min.

c) \(\boxed{\,\lvert q\rvert \approx 0.00677\ \text{ft/min}\!}\)

question: For an unconfined aquifer with a hydraulic conductivity of $K=30 \mathrm{~m} /$ day, two observation wells located 2 km apart measure water levels at 50 m and 40 m, respectively, from the aquifer's base. Calculate the flow rate.
response:
Solution Explanation:

We treat this as horizontal flow in a steady‐state unconfined aquifer. Two observation wells are located 2 km (L = 2000 m) apart, and they measure water‐table elevations (hydraulic head) h₁ = 50 m and h₂ = 40 m above the aquifer base. For an unconfined aquifer, the standard formula for the flow rate per unit width, Q′ (in units of m²/day), between two different heads h₁ and h₂ separated by distance L is:

Q′ = (K / (2 L)) (h₁² − h₂²),

where K is the hydraulic conductivity (here, K = 30 m/day).

Step by step:

1) Compute the difference of squares of the two heads:
   h₁² − h₂² = 50² − 40² = 2500 − 1600 = 900.
2) Multiply by the hydraulic conductivity:
   K (h₁² − h₂²) = 30 × 900 = 27000.
3) Divide by 2 L:
   (K / (2 L)) (h₁² − h₂²) = 27000 / (2 × 2000) = 27000 / 4000 = 6.75.

Hence, the flow rate per unit width Q′ is 6.75 m²/day. Interpreted in three dimensions, this corresponds to 6.75 m³/day per meter width of the aquifer (perpendicular to the flow).

Final Result:

\[
\boxed{6.75 \text{ m}^2/\text{day}}
\]

question:
A well with a diameter of 0.4 m fully penetrates a confined aquifer that is 25 m thick, with a permeability coefficient of $12 \mathrm{~m} /$ day. The well is positioned at the center of a circular island with a radius of 1 km. The water level at the island's boundary is 80 m.

(a) What is the required pumping rate for the well to maintain the water level at 60 m above the bottom?

(b) For part (a), calculate the groundwater travel time from the island's boundary to the well. The aquifer's porosity is 0.25.
response:
Solution Explanation:

We model the well as fully penetrating a confined (artesian) aquifer of thickness b = 25 m and permeability coefficient K = 12 m/day. The island radius is R = 1000 m, and the well radius (from diameter 0.4 m) is r_w = 0.20 m. The water level (head) is 80 m at the boundary and 60 m at the well, both measured from the same aquifer bottom datum. The porosity for part (b) is n_e = 0.25.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
a) Pumping rate Q to maintain the drawdown

1) Confined radial flow.  
   For steady‐state radial flow in a confined aquifer, the discharge Q is given by  
   Q = 2πT (h₁ − h₂) / ln(R / r_w),  
   where  
   – T = transmissivity = K·b,  
   – h₁ = head at outer boundary = 80 m,  
   – h₂ = head at the well = 60 m,  
   – R = 1000 m (island radius),  
   – r_w = 0.20 m (well radius).

2) Compute the transmissivity T.  
   T = K b = (12 m/day) × (25 m) = 300 m²/day.

3) Compute Q.  
   h₁ − h₂ = 80 m − 60 m = 20 m,  
   ln(R / r_w) = ln(1000 / 0.20) = ln(5000).  

   Numerically,  
   ln(5000) ≈ 8.517,  
   so  
   Q = [ 2π × 300 m²/day × 20 m ] / 8.517  
     ≈ 4425 m³/day.

Hence, 
a) 
\[
\boxed{Q \approx 4425 \text{ m}^3/\text{day}}
\]

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
b) Groundwater travel time from the island boundary to the well

In a homogeneous, fully confined, steady‐state radial flow, the average linear velocity at radius r is  
v(r) = Q / [2π r b n_e],  
where n_e is the effective porosity. The travel time T_travel from r_w to R is found by integrating dr / v(r):

\[
T_{\mathrm{travel}}
= \int_{r_w}^R \frac{dr}{v(r)}
= \int_{r_w}^R \frac{2\pi\,r\,b\,n_e}{Q}\,dr
= \frac{2\pi b n_e}{Q}
  \int_{r_w}^R r\,dr
= \frac{2\pi b n_e}{Q}\,\frac{R^2 - r_w^2}{2}.
\]

Simplify to  
\[
T_{\mathrm{travel}}
= \frac{\pi\,b\,n_e\,(R^2 - r_w^2)}{Q}.
\]

Plugging in the numbers:  
– b = 25 m,  
– n_e = 0.25,  
– R = 1000 m,  
– r_w = 0.20 m,  
– Q ≈ 4425 m³/day.

Then  
R² − r_w² ≈ 1000² − 0.2² = 1{,}000{,}000 − 0.04 ≈ 999{,}999.96 ≈ 1.0 × 10⁶.  

So the numerator is  
0.25 × π × 25 × (1.0 × 10⁶) ≈ 6.25 π × 10⁶.  

Numerically,  
6.25 π × 10⁶ ≈ 1.9635 × 10⁷,  
and dividing by Q ≈ 4425 m³/day gives  

T_travel ≈ (1.9635 × 10⁷) / 4425 ≈ 4440 days,

which is about 12.2 years.

Hence, 
b) 
\[
\boxed{T_{\mathrm{travel}} \approx 4440 \text{ days (about 12.2 years)}}
\]

question: A well with a diameter of 0.3 m completely penetrates an unconfined aquifer. The water table is positioned 70 m above the base, and the permeability coefficient is $20 \mathrm{~m} /$ day. The well is operated such that the water level within it consistently stays 20 m beneath the initial water table. The water table remains unaffected at a distance of 1 km. Calculate the well's flow rate.
response:
Step-by-step reasoning:

1) Identify the governing equation.  
   For radial (approximately horizontal) flow to a fully penetrating well in an unconfined aquifer with negligible drawdown at large radius, the steady‐state Dupuit–Thiem formula is:  

   Q = π K (H₀² - H_w²) / ln(R/r_w),

   where  
   • Q is the volumetric flow rate (m³/day),  
   • K is the hydraulic conductivity (m/day),  
   • H₀ is the initial hydraulic head above the base of the aquifer at large radius (m),  
   • H_w is the hydraulic head above the base of the aquifer in the well (m),  
   • R is the radius of influence, i.e., distance at which drawdown is effectively zero (m), and  
   • r_w is the well radius (m).  

2) Extract data from the problem.  
   • Diameter of well = 0.3 m ⇒ radius r_w = 0.15 m.  
   • Initial water table = 70 m above the base of the aquifer, hence H₀ = 70 m.  
   • The well is operated so that the water level is 20 m below the initial water table. Therefore the water level in the well is 70 - 20 = 50 m above the base ⇒ H_w = 50 m.  
   • K = 20 m/day.  
   • Radius of influence R = 1000 m.  

3) Plug in numbers.  

   (i) Compute the difference H₀² - H_w²:  
       H₀² = 70² = 4900,  
       H_w² = 50² = 2500,  
       ⇒ H₀² - H_w² = 4900 - 2500 = 2400.  

   (ii) Compute the natural log ln(R/r_w):  
       R/r_w = 1000 / 0.15 = 6666.666…,  
       ln(6666.666…) ≈ 8.803 (approximately).  

   (iii) Substitute into the Dupuit–Thiem formula:  
       Q = (π × 20 × 2400) / ln(6666.666…)  
         = (π × 48,000) / 8.803.  

   (iv) Numerically evaluate:  
       Numerator = 48,000 × π ≈ 150,796,  
       Divide by 8.803 ⇒ Q ≈ 150,796 / 8.803 ≈ 17,130 m³/day.  

Conclusion:  
The well’s flow rate is approximately 17,100 m³/day.

Final result:  
\(\boxed{Q \approx 1.7\times 10^4 \text{ m}^3/\text{day}}\).

question:
From a well that fully penetrates a confined aquifer, the following drawdowns were recorded from an observation well located 200 ft from the source well, which is being pumped at a rate of 500 gpm. Use the type-curve method to find the transmissivity and storage coefficient.

| Time since pumping (min) | 0 | 1 | 1.5 | 2.0 | 2.5 | 3 | 4 | 5 |  | 8 |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| Drawdown (ft) | 0 | 0.66 | 0.87 | 0.99 | 1.11 | 1.21 | 1.36 | 1.49 |  | 1.75 |
| Time | 10 | 14 | 18 | 24 | 30 | 40 | 50 | 60 | 100 | 150 |
| Drawdown | 1.86 | 2.08 | 2.20 | 2.36 | 2.49 | 2.65 | 2.78 | 2.88 | 3.16 | 3.42 |
| Time | 180 | 210 | 240 |  |  |  |  |  |  |  |
| Drawdown | 3.51 | 3.61 | 3.67 |  |  |  |  |  |  |  |
response:
Solution Explanation (Type‐Curve Method via the Theis/Cooper–Jacob Approximation)

We have a pumping well discharging at Q = 500 gpm from a confined aquifer. An observation well at r = 200 ft from the pumping well records the drawdown s versus time t (in minutes). We wish to find the transmissivity T and the storage coefficient S using the type‐curve (Theis) method. A standard practical shortcut to the full type‐curve matching is the Cooper–Jacob semilog approximation for later times; this is often taught as an equivalent approach to reading shifts from the type curve.

─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1) Convert the Pumping Rate into Consistent Units
─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Although Q is given as 500 gpm, if we wish to express T in ft²/day, then Q must be converted to ft³/day:

• 1 gallon = 0.1337 ft³  
• 1 gpm = 0.1337 ft³/min = 0.1337 ft³/min × 1440 min/day = 192.5 ft³/day  
• Hence, Q = 500 gpm = 500 × 192.5 ft³/day = 96 250 ft³/day  

─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2) Semilog Straight‐Line (Cooper–Jacob) Approximation
─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

For times sufficiently large (so that well‐bore storage and early‐time effects are negligible), the Theis equation can be approximated by the Cooper–Jacob straight‐line form on a plot of s versus log t:

(1)  s(t) ≈ (2.3 Q) / (4 π T)  ·  log₁₀( 2.25 T t / (r² S) ).

From this linear relation in s vs. log t:

a) The slope m of the straight line (in ft per log cycle) is  
   m = (2.3 Q) / (4 π T).  

b) The intercept time t₀ is the time at which the straight line would give zero drawdown (by extrapolation). Then,  
   2.25 T t₀ / (r² S) = 1  ⟹  t₀ = (r² S) / (2.25 T).

Rearranging solves for S once T is known.

─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3) Determining the Slope m from the Field Data
─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Looking at the later‐time data, one finds that from t = 24 min (s = 2.36 ft) to t = 240 min (s = 3.67 ft), the drawdown increases by about 1.31 ft over exactly one log cycle (since 240 min / 24 min = 10). Thus,

m ≈ 1.31 ft per log cycle.

─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4) Solve for Transmissivity T
─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Using the Cooper–Jacob slope formula:

m = (2.3 Q) / (4 π T)

⇒  T = (2.3 Q) / (4 π m).

With Q = 96 250 ft³/day and m = 1.31 ft:

T = [2.3 × 96 250 (ft³/day)] / [4 π × 1.31 (ft)]
  = (221 375) / [4 π × 1.31]
  ≈ 13 400 ft²/day.

─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
5) Solve for Storage Coefficient S
─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Next, to find t₀ (the “intercept time” for s → 0 on the semilog straight line):  
We fit s(t) = m log₁₀(t) + b through the data and extrapolate to s = 0. From the illustrative fit:

• Using points (t, s) = (24 min, 2.36 ft) and (240 min, 3.67 ft), one finds t₀ ≈ 0.376 min by linear extrapolation.  
• Convert t₀ to days:  
  t₀(day) = 0.376 min × (1 day / 1440 min) ≈ 2.61 × 10⁻⁴ days.

From the relation

t₀ = (r² S) / (2.25 T),

we solve for S:

S = (2.25 T t₀) / r².

Substitute T ≈ 13 400 ft²/day, r = 200 ft, and t₀ ≈ 2.61 × 10⁻⁴ day:

S = (2.25 × 13 400 ft²/day × 2.61 × 10⁻⁴ day) / (200 ft)²
  ≈ (2.25 × 13 400 × 2.61 × 10⁻⁴) / 40 000
  ≈ (7.90) / 40 000
  ≈ 2.0 × 10⁻⁴.

─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Final Results
─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Thus, from type‐curve (Cooper–Jacob) analysis of the drawdown data:

• Transmissivity:  
  T ≈ 1.34 × 10⁴ ft²/day

• Storage Coefficient:  
  S ≈ 2.0 × 10⁻⁴

In boxed LaTeX form:

\boxed{T \approx 1.34 \times 10^{4}\,\text{ft}^{2}/\text{day}, \quad S \approx 2.0\times 10^{-4}}

question:
A 2-hour test was conducted on a confined aquifer at a flow rate of 400 gpm, with drawdowns recorded from several wells. Use the type-curve method to calculate the transmissivity and storage coefficient.

| Well number: | 1 | 2 | 3 | 4 | 5 | 6 | 7 |
| :--- | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: |
| Distance (ft) | 29 | 35 | 44 | 60 | 85 | 100 | 163 |
| Drawdown $(\mathrm{ft})$ | 14.9 | 13.8 | 12.7 | 11.7 | 10.1 | 9.6 | 7 |
response:
Solution Explanation (Step by Step)

We wish to determine the transmissivity T and storage coefficient S of a confined aquifer, given observations of steady drawdown at multiple wells after 2 hours of pumping at Q = 400 gpm.  One common way to do this (in lieu of directly matching Theis type curves) is via the Cooper–Jacob distance‐drawdown method (a simplified analytical approach that is equivalent to matching the Theis type curve for a single time).

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1) Convert pumping rate to consistent units
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Typically, for the Theis (or Cooper–Jacob) equation in consistent (SI‐like) units, we want Q in ft³/min (if time is in minutes and distances are in feet). Since Q is 400 gpm and 1 gallon = 0.1337 ft³,

Q (ft³/min) = 400 (gpm) × 0.1337 (ft³/gallon) ≈ 53.48 ft³/min.

We will keep time t in minutes (120 min) and distance r in feet, so that T will emerge in units of ft²/min.  (Often one finally converts T to ft²/day or to gpd/ft.)

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2) The Cooper–Jacob distance‐drawdown form
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

For a confined aquifer at a fixed time t, the linearized Theis (Cooper–Jacob) solution for drawdown s at radius r is

s(r) = (Q / 4πT) ln( 2.25 T t / (r² S) ),  

which can be rewritten as

s(r) 
  = (Q / 4 π T ) [ ln(2.25 T t) - ln(r²) - ln(S) ]
  = (Q / 4 π T ) ln(2.25 T t / S )   −   (Q / 4 π T ) ln(r²).  

Observe that ln(r²) = 2 ln(r).  Defining

s(r) = A + B ln(r),  

we identify

B = − (Q / 2 π T),  
A = (Q / 4 π T) ln( (2.25 T t) / S ).  

Hence, if we plot s versus ln(r) for all observation wells at the same time t, the slope of the best‐fit line gives T, and the intercept gives S.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3) Prepare data for linear regression of s vs. ln(r)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Below are the distances r (ft), drawdowns s (ft) after 2 hours (120 min), and ln(r).

 ┌─────────────┬─────────┬─────────┬─────────────┐
 │ Well number │   r (ft)│ s (ft)  │ ln(r)       │
 ├─────────────┼─────────┼─────────┼─────────────┤
 │     1       │   29    │  14.9   │ 3.3673      │
 │     2       │   35    │  13.8   │ 3.5553      │
 │     3       │   44    │  12.7   │ 3.7842      │
 │     4       │   60    │  11.7   │ 4.0943      │
 │     5       │   85    │  10.1   │ 4.4427      │
 │     6       │   100   │   9.6   │ 4.6052      │
 │     7       │   163   │   7.0   │ 5.0938      │
 └─────────────┴─────────┴─────────┴─────────────┘

Perform a linear regression to fit

s = A + B ln(r).

One finds (by summing over the wells and applying the standard least‐squares formulas):

• Slope B ≈ −4.33  
• Intercept A ≈ 29.30  

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
4) Solve for T from the slope
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

We have identified

B = − Q / (2 π T).

Hence

T = − Q / (2 π B).  

Since Q = 53.48 ft³/min and B = − 4.33,

T = 53.48 / [ 2 π × 4.33 ]  
  ≈ 53.48 / (6.2832 × 4.33 )  
  ≈ 53.48 / 27.22  
  ≈ 1.96 ft²/min.

Often, transmissivity is finally reported in ft²/day:

1.96 ft²/min × 1440 min/day ≈ 2828 ft²/day.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
5) Solve for S from the intercept
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Recall

A = (Q / 4 π T) ln( (2.25 T t)/S ).  

We rearrange for S:

(4 π T / Q) A = ln( (2.25 T t) / S ),  
exp( (4 π T / Q) A ) = (2.25 T t ) / S,  

thus

S = (2.25 T t ) / exp( (4 π T / Q) A ).  

Plug in  
• T = 1.96 ft²/min,  
• t = 120 min,  
• Q = 53.48 ft³/min,  
• A = 29.30.  

First compute α = (4 π T)/Q:

α = (4 π × 1.96) / 53.48 ≈ 0.46,

so

α A ≈ 0.46 × 29.30 ≈ 13.48,  
exp(13.48) ≈ 7.1×10⁵ (approximately).

Then the numerator is 2.25 × 1.96 × 120 ≈ 529.2, giving

S = 529.2 / (7.1×10⁵) ≈ 7.4×10⁻⁴.

This is a plausible storativity for a confined aquifer.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Final Results
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Transmissivity (as ft²/day) and storage coefficient:

• T ≈ 2.8×10³ ft²/day,  
• S ≈ 7.4×10⁻⁴.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Answer
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

\[
\boxed{
T \approx 2.8 \times 10^{3}\,\text{ft}^{2}\!/\text{day}, 
\quad 
S \approx 7.4 \times 10^{-4}.
}
\]

question:
Consider a test conducted on a confined aquifer with a thickness of 50 m, where the following observations were recorded. The lab test determined the coefficient of permeability to be $25 \mathrm{~m} /$ day. Using the type-curve method, determine the rate of pumping and the storage coefficient of the aquifer given that $r=61 \mathrm{~m}$.

| Time (min) | 1 | 3 | 5 | 10 | 18 | 30 | 50 | 100 | 150 | 210 | 240 |
| :--- | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: |
| Drawdown (m) | 0.2 | 0.37 | 0.45 | 0.57 | 0.67 | 0.76 | 0.85 | 0.97 | 1.05 | 1.1 | 1.12 |
response:
Solution Explanation (Step by Step):

We are given a pumping test on a confined aquifer of thickness b = 50 m, where the laboratory‐measured coefficient of permeability is K = 25 m day⁻¹. Hence, the transmissivity T of the aquifer (assuming a uniform formation) is  
T = K b = (25 m day⁻¹)(50 m) = 1250 m² day⁻¹.

We have drawdown data s versus time t (in minutes), at a radial distance r = 61 m from the pumped well. The question asks us—using a type‐curve (Theis) method or, equivalently here, the Cooper–Jacob semilog approximation—to determine:  
1) The pumping rate Q (in m³ day⁻¹).  
2) The storage coefficient S of the confined aquifer.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1) Estimate Q using Cooper–Jacob’s semilog approximation

The late‐time Theis solution for drawdown in a confined aquifer is often approximated (Cooper–Jacob) by:

s(t) = (Q / (4 π T)) ln(2.25 T t / (r² S))   in natural‐log form,

or, in base‐10 logs,

s(t) = (2.3 Q / (4 π T)) log₁₀(2.25 T t / (r² S)).

Define the semilog slope m (or s_p) as the change in drawdown per log‐cycle of time:

m = (Δs) / (Δlog₁₀(t))  =  (2.3 Q) / (4 π T).

From the given data, let us pick two “late‐time” points to approximate the slope:

• At t₁ = 100 min,  s₁ = 0.97 m.  
• At t₂ = 240 min,  s₂ = 1.12 m.

Compute:  
Δs = s₂ − s₁ = 1.12 − 0.97 = 0.15 m,  
Δlog₁₀(t) = log₁₀(240) − log₁₀(100) = log₁₀(2.4) ≈ 0.38.

Hence, the slope m is approximately

m = 0.15 / 0.38 ≈ 0.395 m (log‑cycle)⁻¹.

From Cooper–Jacob’s formula in base‐10 log form,  
m = (2.3 Q) / (4 π T)  ⟹  Q = (4 π T m) / 2.3.

Plugging in T = 1250 m² day⁻¹ and m ≈ 0.395:

•  4 π  ≈ 12.566,  
•  4 π T  ≈ 12.566 × 1250 ≈ 15 708,  
•  (4 π T) m  ≈ 15 708 × 0.395 ≈ 6203.6,  
•  Q = 6203.6 / 2.3 ≈ 2700 m³ day⁻¹.

Therefore, the estimated pumping rate is

Q ≈ 2700 m³ day⁻¹.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2) Estimate the Storage Coefficient S

Again from the Cooper–Jacob approximation, one may write

s(t) = (2.3 Q / (4 π T)) log₁₀(t / t₀),

where t₀ is the so‐called “zero‐drawdown intercept” when plotting s versus log₁₀(t). Equivalently,

2.25 T t₀ / (r² S) = 1   ⟹   S = (2.25 T t₀) / r².

To find t₀, one can use the fact that when s = 0 on the same semilog straight line, t = t₀. A practical way is to pick one of our data points and back‐solve for t₀:

s(t₁) = (2.3 Q / (4 π T)) [log₁₀(t₁) − log₁₀(t₀)].

Taking t₁ = 100 min, s₁ = 0.97 m:

0.97 = (m) [log₁₀(100) − log₁₀(t₀)],
where m = 0.395 from above. Hence,

log₁₀(100) − log₁₀(t₀) = 0.97 / 0.395 ≈ 2.46  ⟹
2 − log₁₀(t₀) = 2.46  ⟹  log₁₀(t₀) = 2 − 2.46 = −0.46  ⟹  t₀ ≈ 10⁻⁰⋅⁴⁶ ≈ 0.35 min.

Since T is in m² day⁻¹, we must convert t₀ to days:  
t₀ (days) = 0.35 min / 1440 min day⁻¹ ≈ 2.43×10⁻⁴ days.

Now use

S = (2.25 T t₀) / r².

Substitute T = 1250 m² day⁻¹, t₀ = 2.43×10⁻⁴ days, and r = 61 m:

S = [2.25 × 1250 × (2.43×10⁻⁴)] / (61)²  
  = (2812.5 × 2.43×10⁻⁴) / 3721  
  ≈ 0.6825 / 3721  
  ≈ 1.83×10⁻⁴.

Hence, the estimated storativity of this confined aquifer is on the order of 10⁻⁴, as is typical.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Answer

Thus, using the type‐curve (Cooper–Jacob) method and the given data:

• The pumping rate is 
Q ≈ 2700 m³ day⁻¹.

• The storage coefficient is 
S ≈ 1.8×10⁻⁴.

In LaTeX format:

\[
\boxed{Q \approx 2700\text{ m}^3/\text{day}, \quad S \approx 1.8\times 10^{-4}.}
\]

question:
During a confined aquifer test, the following drawdowns were recorded at different observation wells 502 minutes after pumping started at a rate of $300 \mathrm{~m}^{3} /$ day.

| Well number: | 1 | 2 | 3 | 4 | 5 |
| :--- | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: |
| Distance $(\mathrm{m})$ | 4.6 | 10.4 | 20 | 34.5 | 65.8 |
| Drawdown $(\mathrm{m})$ | 1.35 | 0.9 | 0.65 | 0.41 | 0.20 |

Calculate the transmissivity and storage coefficient using the type-curve method.
response:
Solution Explanation (Step by Step)

We have a constant‐rate pump test in a confined aquifer:  
• Pumping rate: Q = 300 m³/day  
• Time of measurement: t = 502 minutes after pumping began  
• Measured drawdowns s at various distances r from the pumping well (see table)

To find the transmissivity T and storativity (storage coefficient) S from these drawdown data (all taken at the same time t but at different radii r), one can use the so‐called “distance‐drawdown” version of the Theis (or Cooper–Jacob) approximation.  

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1) Convert the pumping time into days
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Since T is ordinarily expressed in m²/day, the time t must also be in days.  
t (in days) = 502 min ÷ 1440 (min/day) ≈ 0.3486 days  

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2) The Cooper–Jacob distance‐drawdown approximation
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
For large t (small dimensionless parameter u), the Theis solution for a confined aquifer can be approximated by

s(r,t) ≈ (Q / 4 π T) ⋅ ln( 2.25 T t / (r² S) ),

where  
• s(r,t) is drawdown [m] at radius r [m], time t [days],  
• Q is the constant pumping rate [m³/day],  
• T is transmissivity [m²/day],  
• S is storativity (dimensionless).  

Rewriting,
s(r) = A − B ln(r),  
where the slope B and intercept A relate to T and S as follows:

• B = 2 (Q / (4 π T)) = Q / (2 π T),  
• A = (Q / (4 π T)) ln(2.25 T t / S).  

Hence once we fit s vs ln(r) to a straight line of the form  
s(r) = a + b ln(r),  
we identify  
b = −B  ⇒  B = −b,  
a = A.  

Then we solve for T and S.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3) Perform a linear regression of s versus ln(r)
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Below are the measured (r, s) and their ln(r).  

┌────────────────────┬─────────────────┬───────────────────┐
│   Well radius r    │  Drawdown s(m)  │  x = ln(r)        │
├────────────────────┼─────────────────┼───────────────────┤
│ 4.6 m              │ 1.35 m          │ 1.5261            │
│ 10.4 m             │ 0.90 m          │ 2.3418            │
│ 20 m               │ 0.65 m          │ 2.9957            │
│ 34.5 m             │ 0.41 m          │ 3.5410            │
│ 65.8 m             │ 0.20 m          │ 4.1882            │
└────────────────────┴─────────────────┴───────────────────┘

A least‐squares fit of s = a + b ln(r) over these five points gives approximately

a  ≈ 1.95,  
b  ≈ −0.43.

Hence the best‐fit line is  
s(r) ≈ 1.95 − 0.43 ln(r).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4) Extract T from the slope
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
We have identified b = −B and B = Q / (2 π T).  Therefore,

B = −b = 0.43  ⇒  0.43 = Q / (2 π T).

Hence,

T = Q / (2 π B) = 300 m³/day / [2 π × 0.43].  

Numerically,

2 π × 0.43 ≈ 2.70,  
so  
T ≈ 300 / 2.70 ≈ 111 m²/day.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
5) Extract S from the intercept
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
From the Cooper–Jacob form,

A = (Q / (4 π T)) ln(2.25 T t / S).

We found a ≈ 1.95 from the fit, and that corresponds to the theoretical intercept A.  Therefore,

1.95 = (Q / (4 π T)) ln(2.25 T t / S).

We already have  
Q / (4 π T) ≈ 300 / (4 π × 111) ≈ 0.21  
(to two decimals), and  
t = 0.3486 days.  

Hence

1.95 / 0.21 = ln( (2.25 × 111 × 0.3486) / S )  ⇒  
ln( (…numerical…) / S ) ≈ 9.29  (approximately).

Compute the numerical product in the numerator:

2.25 × 111 × 0.3486 ≈ 87.7.

Thus,

ln( 87.7 / S ) ≈ 9.29  ⇒  87.7 / S ≈ e^(9.29).

Since e^(9.29) is roughly 1.08×10^4, one gets

S ≈ 87.7 / (1.08 × 10^4) ≈ 0.0081 to 0.0096

(depending on the precise exponential value).  A more precise calculation yields around S ≈ 0.009–0.01.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Final Results
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Transmissivity:  
T ≈ 1.1 × 10² m²/day,

Storage Coefficient:  
S ≈ 0.01.

Thus, to one or two significant figures:

\[
\boxed{
T \approx 110 \,\text{m}^2/\text{day}, 
\quad
S \approx 0.01.
}
\]

question: In an unstable flow scenario, the provided data are: $\mathrm{Q}=0.1 \mathrm{cfs}$, $T=650 \mathrm{ft}^{2}/$ day, $t=35$ days, $r=0.6 \mathrm{ft}$, and $S=6 \times 10^{-3}$. Determine the drawdown.
response:
Step-by-Step Solution

We use the classic Theis (1935) equation for transient (unsteady) radial flow to a well in a confined aquifer.  Denoting the drawdown by s(r,t), the Theis equation reads:

(1)  s(r,t) = (Q / (4 \pi T)) ⋅ W(u),

where the dimensionless parameter u is given by

(2)  u = (r² S) / (4 T t),

and W(u) = −Ei(−u) is the well function, which for very small u can be approximated by the series expansion

(3)  W(u) ≈ −γ − ln(u),  

with γ ≈ 0.5772 denoting the Euler–Mascheroni constant.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1) Compute the dimensionless parameter u

Given data:  
• Q = 0.1 ft³/s,  
• T = 650 ft²/day,  
• t = 35 days,  
• r = 0.6 ft,  
• S = 6 × 10⁻³.

First,  
r² = (0.6)² = 0.36 ft².  
Hence,  
r² S = 0.36 × 6×10⁻³ = 0.00216.  

Next,  
4 T t = 4 × (650 ft²/day) × (35 days) = 4 × 650 × 35 = 91 000 ft².  

Thus,  
u = (r² S) / (4 T t) = 0.00216 / 91 000 ≈ 2.37 × 10⁻⁸.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2) Approximate the well function W(u) for small u

For u ≪ 1,  
W(u) ≈ −γ − ln(u).  

We compute ln(u):  
u = 2.37 × 10⁻⁸ ⇒ ln(u) = ln(2.37 × 10⁻⁸) = ln(2.37) − 8 ln(10).  

Numerically,  
ln(2.37) ≈ 0.863,  
ln(10) ≈ 2.302585 ⇒ 8 ln(10) ≈ 18.42068.  
Therefore,  
ln(2.37 × 10⁻⁸) ≈ 0.863 − 18.42068 = −17.557.  

Hence,  
W(u) ≈ −γ − ln(u) = −0.5772 − (−17.557) = 16.98 (approximately).

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3) Convert Q to consistent units

We have Q = 0.1 ft³/s, but T is in ft²/day, so convert Q to ft³/day:

1 ft³/s = 86 400 ft³/day,  
so  
Q = 0.1 ft³/s = 0.1 × 86 400 = 8 640 ft³/day.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
4) Substitute into the Theis equation

From Equation (1),  
s(r,t) = (Q / (4 π T)) × W(u).

Compute the prefactor Q / (4 π T):

• 4 π T = 4 × π × 650.  
Numerically,  
4 π ≈ 12.5664,  
12.5664 × 650 ≈ 8 161.16.  

Thus,  
Q / (4 π T) = (8 640 ft³/day) / (8 161.16 ft²/day) ≈ 1.058 ft/day.

Finally,  
s(r,t) = (1.058 ft/day) × 16.98 ≈ 17.96 ft.

Hence, the drawdown at r = 0.6 ft after 35 days is about 18 feet.

\boxed{17.96\text{ ft (approximately)}}

question:
An artesian aquifer was continuously pumped by a well at a rate of 500 gpm. After a period of 200 days, drawdowns were recorded in three observation wells. Determine the transmissivity and storage coefficient of the aquifer using the Cooper-Jacob method. Additionally, verify if this method is suitable for all the wells.

| Distance from pumped well (ft) | Drawdown $(\mathrm{ft})$ |
| :---: | :---: |
| 100 | 8.5 |
| 1000 | 5.67 |
| 10,000 | 2.84 |
response:
Solution Explanation (Step by Step)

We have an artesian (confined) aquifer pumped at a constant rate Q = 500 gpm for a time t = 200 days. Three observation wells at distances r = 100 ft, 1000 ft, and 10 000 ft record drawdowns s = 8.5 ft, 5.67 ft, and 2.84 ft, respectively. We wish to determine the transmissivity T and the storage coefficient S using the Cooper–Jacob approximation to the Theis solution. Then we will check the suitability of the method at each observation well.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1) Cooper–Jacob distance–drawdown formula
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Under the Cooper–Jacob (late-time) approximation, the drawdown at distance r and time t is often written (in base-10 logarithms) as

(1)   s(r) 
   = (2.3 Q) / (4 π T)  ×  log₁₀[ (2.25 T t) / (r² S ) ]  ,

where  
• s(r) is drawdown at radius r,  
• Q is the pumping rate (L³/T),  
• T is transmissivity (L²/T),  
• t is time (T),  
• S is the (dimensionless) storage coefficient.

On a plot of s versus log₁₀(r), this formula predicts a straight line whose slope (with respect to log₁₀(r)) is

(2)   slope = (2.3 Q) / (4 π T)   (in consistent units).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2) Converting pumping rate to consistent units
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Since we typically express T in ft²/day, we must convert Q = 500 gpm into ft³/day:

• 1 gallon ≈ 0.1337 ft³,  
• Hence, 500 gpm = 500×0.1337 ft³/min = 66.85 ft³/min.  
• There are 1440 min in a day, so  
  Q = 66.85 ft³/min × 1440 min/day ≈ 96 324 ft³/day.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3) Finding T from the slope
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

We have three data points (r, s).  If the assumptions are valid, plotting s versus log₁₀(r) should lie on a straight line with slope

   slope = Δs / Δlog₁₀(r).

Let us check consistency between pairs of observation wells:

a) Between r₁ = 100 ft (s₁ = 8.5 ft) and r₂ = 1000 ft (s₂ = 5.67 ft):
   • s₂ − s₁ = 5.67 − 8.5 = −2.83.  
   • log₁₀(r₂) − log₁₀(r₁) = log₁₀(1000) − log₁₀(100) = 3 − 2 = 1.  
   • slope = −2.83 / 1 = −2.83 (ft per log cycle).

b) Between r₂ = 1000 ft (s₂ = 5.67 ft) and r₃ = 10 000 ft (s₃ = 2.84 ft):
   • s₃ − s₂ = 2.84 − 5.67 = −2.83.  
   • log₁₀(r₃) − log₁₀(r₂) = 4 − 3 = 1.  
   • slope = −2.83 / 1 = −2.83 (ft per log cycle).

Both intervals give the same (negative) slope of −2.83 ft, which in magnitude is 2.83 ft per log cycle. By the Cooper–Jacob relation (2),

   2.83 = (2.3 Q) / (4 π T),

where Q = 96 324 ft³/day.  Solve for T:

   T 
   = (2.3 × 96 324) / [4 π × 2.83].
   
Numerically,  
• Numerator = 2.3 × 96 324 ≈ 221 545.2.  
• Denominator = 4 π × 2.83.  
  First  4 × 2.83 = 11.32,  
  then  11.32 × π ≈ 35.56.  

Hence,

   T ≈ 221 545.2 / 35.56 ≈ 6230 ft²/day.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4) Finding S from one of the observation wells
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Using equation (1),

   s(r) = (2.3 Q)/(4 π T) × log₁₀[(2.25 T t)/(r² S)].

We already know the factor (2.3 Q)/(4 π T) = 2.83 ft/log-cycle (from above).  
Thus,

   s(r) = 2.83 × log₁₀[(2.25 T t)/(r² S)].

Rearrange for S if we plug in each well’s (r, s).

(a) r = 100 ft, s = 8.5 ft  
    8.5 = 2.83 × log₁₀[(2.25 × 6230 × 200) / (100² × S)].  
    8.5 / 2.83 ≈ 3,  
    so  log₁₀[...] = 3  ⟹  [...] = 10³ = 1000.  

    Numerator = 2.25 × 6230 × 200 = 2 803 500.  
    Denominator = 100² × S = 10 000 × S.  
    So   2 803 500 / (10 000 × S) = 1000  
          2 803 500 / 10 000 = 280.35,  
          280.35 / S = 1000  ⟹  S = 0.280.  

(b) r = 1000 ft, s = 5.67 ft  
    5.67 = 2.83 × log₁₀[(2 803 500)/(1 000 000 × S)].  
    5.67 / 2.83 ≈ 2,  
    so  log₁₀[...] = 2  ⟹  [...] = 10² = 100.  

    Thus  (2 803 500)/(1 000 000 × S) = 100  
           2 803 500 = 100 000 000 × S  
           S = 0.0280.  

(c) r = 10 000 ft, s = 2.84 ft  
    2.84 = 2.83 × log₁₀[(2 803 500)/(100 000 000 × S)].  
    2.84 / 2.83 ≈ 1,  
    so  log₁₀[...] = 1  ⟹  [...] = 10¹ = 10.  

    Hence  (2 803 500)/(100 000 000 S) = 10  
           2 803 500 = 1 000 000 000 × S  
           S = 0.00280.  

Notice how the computed storage coefficient S varies drastically depending on which well is used:

• At r = 100 ft  ⇒  S ≈ 0.28  (very large for a confined aquifer),  
• At r = 1000 ft ⇒  S ≈ 0.028,  
• At r = 10 000 ft ⇒ S ≈ 0.0028.

For a truly confined (artesian) aquifer, one typically expects S in the range 10⁻⁵ to 10⁻³ or so. The value S ≈ 0.0028 (from the farthest well) is closest to a reasonable confined-aquifer storage. This discrepancy strongly suggests that the outer well is most representative of true radial (late-time) conditions, whereas the wells near the pumping well may be affected by additional phenomena (partial penetration, wellbore skin, delayed yield from adjacent beds, etc.) that violate Cooper–Jacob’s simplified assumptions.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
5) Conclusion and suitability of the method
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

(a) Transmissivity.  
    From the consistent slope in the distance–drawdown data,  
    T ≈ 6230 ft²/day.

(b) Storage Coefficient.  
    The well at r = 10 000 ft yields an S-value that is realistic for a confined aquifer,  
    S ≈ 2.8×10⁻³.  

Hence,

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Answer:
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

• Using the Cooper–Jacob semilog slope, the transmissivity is  
  a)  
  \[
    \boxed{
      T \;\approx\; 6{,}230 \text{ ft}^2/\text{day}
    }
  \]  

• By matching the farthest observation-well drawdown (where the approximation is more reliable for a confined aquifer), the storage coefficient is  
  b)  
  \[
    \boxed{
      S \;\approx\; 2.8\times 10^{-3}
    }
  \]

Regarding the method’s suitability: The Cooper–Jacob straight-line approximation appears consistent only for the far well at 10 000 ft, which yields a realistic S for an artesian aquifer. The nearer wells (at 100 ft and 1000 ft) give unrealistically large values of S; presumably, local wellbore effects, partial penetration, or delayed yield violate the simplifying assumptions at smaller radii. Thus, the method is not equally suitable for all three observation wells.

question:
From a pumping test conducted on an unconfined aquifer with a thickness of 40 ft, the following drawdown data was recorded from an observation well located 60 ft away from the pumping well. The pumping rate is $1500 \mathrm{gal} / \mathrm{min}$. Calculate the transmissivity and specific yield of the aquifer. Is it appropriate to analyze this as if it were a confined aquifer?

| Time (min) | 30 | 60 | 90 | 120 | 300 | 500 | 1000 | 2400 |
| :--- | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: |
| Drawdown (ft) | 8 | 10.6 | 12.72 | 13.47 | 15.83 | 18.1 | 23.0 | 29.0 |
response:
Solution Explanation (Step-by-Step)

We have an unconfined aquifer of saturated thickness b = 40 ft. A constant‐rate pumping test is conducted at a discharge of Q = 1500 gal min⁻¹ from a well, and the drawdown s(t) is observed at a distance r = 60 ft. The data measured at times t (minutes) are shown in the table:

┌────────────┬───────┬───────┬───────┬───────┬───────┬───────┬────────┬────────┐
│ Time (min) │ 30    │ 60    │ 90    │ 120   │ 300   │ 500   │ 1000   │ 2400   │
├────────────┼───────┼───────┼───────┼───────┼───────┼───────┼────────┼────────┤
│ Drawdown s │ 8 ft  │10.6 ft│12.7 ft│13.5 ft│15.8 ft│18.1 ft│23.0 ft │29.0 ft │
└────────────┴───────┴───────┴───────┴───────┴───────┴───────┴────────┴────────┘

We wish to determine:
• The transmissivity T of the aquifer.  
• The specific yield Sy of the unconfined aquifer.  
• Whether it is appropriate to analyze this test as if it were in a confined aquifer.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1) Converting Pumping Rate to Consistent Units

In many steady‐flow or Theis/Cooper‐Jacob‐type formulae, volumetric flow rates Q are most conveniently used in ft³ min⁻¹ (rather than gallons per minute). Since 1 gallon ≈ 0.13368 ft³,

Q = 1500 gal min⁻¹ × 0.13368 (ft³ gal⁻¹) ≈ 200.52 ft³ min⁻¹.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2) Late‐Time Semilog Analysis (Cooper–Jacob Method)

For an unconfined aquifer, early‐time data are often complicated by so‐called “delayed yield” (Neuman effect). Accordingly, one typically fits the late‐time data to a semilog straight line:
  
  s = (2.3 Q)/(4 π T) · log₁₀ t − (2.3 Q)/(4 π T) · log₁₀ t₀,
  
where t₀ is the “x‐intercept” on the semilog plot (time at which drawdown would go to zero in the idealized straight‐line extension).

Looking at the data from t = 500 min to t = 2400 min often produces a clean semilog straight line for an unconfined aquifer’s late‐time behavior. The pairs (t, s) used:

• (500 min, 18.1 ft)  
• (1000 min, 23.0 ft)  
• (2400 min, 29.0 ft)

Define x = log₁₀(t). Then we fit s vs. x and find the slope m (in ft per log cycle). A quick linear‐regression or two‐point slope yields:

m ≈ 16 ft per log₁₀ cycle.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3) Transmissivity from the Semilog Slope

From the Cooper–Jacob approximation,  
  m = (2.3 Q)/(4 π T).  

Hence,

  T = (2.3 Q) / (4 π m).

We already have Q = 200.52 ft³ min⁻¹ and m = 16 ft log⁻¹(t). Also 4 π ≈ 12.5664. So,

  2.3 × Q = 2.3 × 200.52 = 461.196 (ft³ min⁻¹),
  4 π     = 12.5664,
  4 π m   = 12.5664 × 16 = 201.06.

Therefore,

  T (in ft² min⁻¹) =  461.196 / 201.06  ≈  2.295 ft² min⁻¹.

It is common to express T in ft² day⁻¹. Since 1 day = 1440 min,

  T (in ft² day⁻¹) =  2.295 ft² min⁻¹  ×  1440 min day⁻¹  
                   ≈  3307 ft² day⁻¹.  

------------------------------------------------------------------------------
4) Specific Yield from the Intercept

In the Cooper–Jacob straight‐line form,

  s = m [log₁₀(t) − log₁₀(t₀)],

the intercept time t₀ is found by extending the line to s = 0:

  0 = m [log₁₀(t₀) − log₁₀(t₀)],
  or equivalently log₁₀(t₀) = (some expression),

and numerically one finds t₀ ≈ 37 min from the best‐fit line. For an unconfined (or water‐table) aquifer in large‐time approximation, the Cooper–Jacob storativity S is replaced by the effective specific yield Sy. The usual relationship is

  t₀ = ( r² S ) / ( 4 T )  
  ⇒  S = ( 4 T t₀ ) / r².

But for unconfined tests at late times, S should be interpreted as Sy (specific yield). Substituting:

• T = 2.295 ft² min⁻¹,  
• t₀ = 37 min,  
• r = 60 ft,

we get

  Sy = [ 4 × (2.295 ft² min⁻¹) × (37 min) ] / (60 ft)².

Compute step by step:

  2.295 × 37  = 84.915,  
  multiply by 4 ⇒  4 × 84.915  ≈ 339.66,  
  denominator:  (60)² = 3600,

so

  Sy = 339.66 / 3600  ≈ 0.0944  (i.e. about 9.4%).

A Sy of roughly 9 – 10 % is quite typical for moderately permeable unconfined aquifers.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------
5) Appropriateness of a Confined‐Aquifer Analysis

Because this is an unconfined aquifer, one must be careful with early‐time data (which reflect filling and emptying of pore spaces near the water table). Strictly speaking, the full Theis (confined) solution is not correct in early times for an unconfined aquifer (the classic Neuman solution handles unconfined conditions more rigorously). However, at sufficiently late times, the Cooper–Jacob straight‐line method can still be applied and often gives a reasonable estimate of T and Sy. 

Hence, it is generally not “correct” to analyze all times as if the aquifer were confined; the appropriate method for capturing early‐time effects is different for unconfined conditions. If one restricts attention to late times, a confined‐aquifer (Theis/Cooper–Jacob) type plot can still yield a good approximate T and Sy.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Final Results

1) Transmissivity:  
   T ≈ 3.3 × 10³ ft² day⁻¹.  

2) Specific Yield:  
   Sy ≈ 0.094.  

3) Confined vs. Unconfined?:  
   It is not strictly correct to treat the entire pumping test as if it were in a confined aquifer. You may use a Theis/Cooper–Jacob semilog analysis only for late‐time data in an unconfined test (where delayed‐yield effects have mostly damped out). A truly confined‐aquifer approach is inappropriate for early times because unconfined water‐table effects violate the assumptions of confined‐aquifer theory.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Answer in LaTeX

\[
\boxed{
\text{Transmissivity } T \approx 3.3\times 10^3 \text{ ft}^2/\text{day}, 
\quad
\text{Specific Yield } S_y \approx 0.094. 
}
\]

It is not appropriate to use a confined‐aquifer analysis for the entire unconfined test, although late‐time data can often be fit via semilog to estimate T and Sᵧ.

question: A well with a diameter of 0.4 m completely penetrates a leaky confined aquifer with a hydraulic conductivity of $20 \mathrm{~m} /$ day and a thickness of 30 m. The confining layer has a leakage coefficient of 0.05 per day. If a drawdown of 1 m is observed at 100 m away from the well, determine the steady-state pumping rate of the well.
response:
Solution Explanation (Step by Step):

We have a well of radius rₓ = 0.20 m (since the diameter is 0.40 m) that fully penetrates a leaky confined aquifer of thickness b = 30 m and hydraulic conductivity K = 20 m/day. Hence the aquifer’s transmissivity is  
T = K b = (20 m/day) × (30 m) = 600 m²/day.

The confining layer (aquitard) is characterized by a leakage coefficient L = 0.05 day⁻¹. In many standard notations for leaky aquifers, the leakance is written as K′/b′ or 1/c, and its reciprocal c is called the leakance resistance. Thus,  
c = 1/L = 1 / (0.05 day⁻¹) = 20 days.

In steady‐state radial flow to a fully penetrating well in a leaky aquifer (assuming drawdown s → 0 as r → ∞), the drawdown s(r) satisfies the Hantush solution:

s(r) = [ Q / (2 π T) ] ⋅ [ K₀(r / B) / K₀(rₓ / B) ],

where  
• Q is the (unknown) pumping rate [m³/day],  
• T is the transmissivity [m²/day],  
• K₀ is the modified Bessel function of the second kind of order zero,  
• B = √(T c) is the leakage factor [m],  
• rₓ is the well radius [m], and  
• s(r) is the drawdown at radial distance r.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1) Compute the leakage factor B

We have  
B = √(T c) = √(600 m²/day × 20 days) = √(12 000 m²) ≈ 109.54 m.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2) Evaluate the dimensionless radii

• Well radius term: rₓ/B = 0.20 m / 109.54 m ≈ 0.001826.  
• Observation radius term: r/B = 100 m / 109.54 m ≈ 0.913.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3) Approximate the Bessel function values K₀(x)

a) K₀(0.001826).  
For very small arguments x ≪ 1, one uses the asymptotic form  
K₀(x) ≈ −ln(x/2) − γ,  
where γ ≈ 0.5772 is the Euler–Mascheroni constant.  
Numerically,  
x/2 = 0.001826/2 = 0.000913,  
ln(0.000913) ≈ −7.0027,  
so −ln(x/2) = 7.0027 and then subtract γ ≈ 0.5772, giving  
K₀(0.001826) ≈ 7.0027 − 0.5772 ≈ 6.4255  
(about 6.43).

b) K₀(0.913).  
From tables or numerical approximation, K₀(1) ≈ 0.4210, and K₀(0.9) ≈ 0.4475. Interpolating near x = 0.913 yields approximately  
K₀(0.913) ≈ 0.44–0.45.  
A reasonable estimate is K₀(0.913) ≈ 0.442.

Hence their ratio is  
K₀(0.913)/K₀(0.001826) ≈ 0.442 / 6.43 ≈ 0.0687.
