(b) Given the temperature profile and surface conditions, find the convection height and describe the temperature profile of an ascending plume if the air were completely dry.
response:
First, let us restate the problem clearly.  We have an idealized “morning” environmental temperature profile over Florida given by

\[
T_{\!e}(z)\;=\;
\begin{cases}
10 \;-\;6\,\bigl(z-1\bigr)\quad(\!^\circ\mathrm{C}) 
& \text{if}\quad z \;\ge\; 1\,\mathrm{km},\\[6pt]
20 \;-\;10\,z\quad(\!^\circ\mathrm{C})
& \text{if}\quad z \;<\; 1\,\mathrm{km}.
\end{cases}
\]

In the afternoon, the near‐surface conditions have changed to 
• a surface temperature of \(30^\circ\mathrm{C}\), and 
• a (water vapor) mixing ratio \(w=20\,\mathrm{g\,kg}^{-1}\).

We wish to analyze two scenarios:

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
a) Assuming the air rising from the surface becomes saturated (i.e., forms cumulus clouds) and behaves nearly moist‐adiabatically aloft, what is the maximum height the clouds can reach?

b) If instead the air stays completely dry, at what height does the rising plume lose its positive buoyancy (i.e., what is the “convection height”)?  Also, give the temperature profile of that ascending dry plume.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Below is a step‐by‐step derivation.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1) The environmental temperature profile
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

• For \(0 \le z < 1\,\mathrm{km}\):
\[
T_{\!e}(z)\;=\;20 - 10\,z.
\]
  – At \(z=0\) (surface), \(T_{\!e}(0)=20^\circ\mathrm{C}\).  
  – At \(z=1\) km, \(T_{\!e}(1)=10^\circ\mathrm{C}\).

• For \(z \ge 1\,\mathrm{km}\):
\[
T_{\!e}(z)\;=\;10 \;-\;6\,(z-1).
\]
  – At \(z=1\) km, \(T_{\!e}(1)=10^\circ\mathrm{C}\).  
  – Above \(z=1\) km, the lapse rate is \(6^\circ\mathrm{C}\) per km (a “moderate” lapse rate).

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2) Parcel properties at the surface in the afternoon
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Now the surface parcel (the “air parcel” we follow upward) has:
• \(T_{\!p}(0)=30^\circ\mathrm{C}.\)
• Mixing ratio \(w=20\,\mathrm{g\,kg}^{-1}\).

From standard approximate formulae (or tables), a mixing ratio near \(20\) g kg\(^{-1}\) at 30 °C suggests a dew point around \(24^\circ\mathrm{C}\).  Hence the parcel is not saturated at the surface (its relative humidity is roughly 70–75 %).

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3) Part (a): Maximum height of cumulus (moist‐adiabatic ascent)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Once the parcel lifts and cools dry‐adiabatically until it reaches its lifting condensation level (LCL), it then cools more slowly (moist‐adiabatically).  Let us find the LCL approximately and then compare the parcel’s temperature to the environment.

----------------------------------------
3.1) LCL estimate
----------------------------------------
A common rule of thumb for the LCL (in km) for a surface parcel is about
\[
\Delta z_{\mathrm{LCL}} 
\;\approx\; 0.125\,\bigl(T - T_{\mathrm{dew}}\bigr)\quad\bigl[\mathrm{km}\bigr],
\]
where \(T\) and \(T_{\mathrm{dew}}\) are in °C.  Since 
\[
T = 30^\circ\mathrm{C},
\quad
T_{\mathrm{dew}}\approx 24^\circ\mathrm{C},
\]
we get
\[
\Delta z_{\mathrm{LCL}} \;\approx\; 0.125 \times (30 - 24)\;=\;0.75\,\mathrm{km}.
\]

Hence the parcel first travels about \(0.75\,\mathrm{km}\) dry‐adiabatically before it becomes saturated.

----------------------------------------
3.2) Parcel temperature at the LCL
----------------------------------------
Dry‐adiabatic lapse rate \(\Gamma_{\mathrm{d}}\approx 9.8^\circ\mathrm{C\,km}^{-1}\).  
Lifting from \(T_{\!p}(0)=30^\circ\mathrm{C}\) over \(0.75\) km gives
\[
T_{\!p}\bigl(0.75\bigr)
\;=\;
30^\circ\mathrm{C} \;-\;9.8\,(\,0.75\,)
\;\approx\;
30 \;-\;7.35
\;=\;
22.65^\circ\mathrm{C}\quad\text{(parcel at LCL)}.
\]

Meanwhile, at \(z=0.75\,\mathrm{km}\), the environmental temperature (from \(20-10z\)) is
\[
T_{\!e}(0.75)
\;=\;
20 - 10 \times 0.75
\;=\;
20 - 7.5
\;=\;12.5^\circ\mathrm{C}.
\]
Thus, at the LCL, the parcel \((22.65^\circ\mathrm{C})\) is still about \(10^\circ\mathrm{C}\) warmer than environment.

----------------------------------------
3.3) Above the LCL: moist‐adiabatic vs. environmental lapse rate
----------------------------------------
• From the LCL upward, the parcel cools at a moist‐adiabatic lapse rate, \(\Gamma_{\mathrm{m}}\).  Under high moisture (20 g kg\(^{-1}\)), \(\Gamma_{\mathrm{m}}\) is typically around \(4\,\text{to}\,6^\circ\mathrm{C\,km}^{-1}\).  Let us take \(\Gamma_{\mathrm{m}}\approx 5^\circ\mathrm{C\,km}^{-1}\) for a rough average in the lower few kilometers.

• From \(z=0.75\) km to \(z=1\) km, the environment still follows \(20-10z\).  Over \(0.25\) km, the parcel cools by roughly \(5\times 0.25=1.25^\circ\mathrm{C}\).  Its temperature at \(z=1\) km is 
\[
22.65 - 1.25\;=\;21.4^\circ\mathrm{C}.
\]
Meanwhile \(T_{\!e}(1)=10^\circ\mathrm{C}\).  The parcel is now \(21.4-10=11.4^\circ\mathrm{C}\) warmer than environment—still very buoyant.

• For \(z>1\) km, the environment cools at \(6^\circ\mathrm{C}\,\mathrm{km}^{-1}\).  Our parcel’s moist‐adiabatic slope (\(\approx5^\circ\mathrm{C\,km}^{-1}\)) is smaller in magnitude.  Therefore, as \(z\) increases, the parcel remains warmer than the environment by an ever‐increasing margin (the difference grows by about 1 °C per km).  Mathematically, there is no height (in the given linear profile) at which the parcel’s temperature becomes equal to (or cooler than) the environment.  

∴ Under these assumptions (no upper inversion given), the cumulus cloud can continue to rise (remain positively buoyant) up toward the tropopause.  The data provided do not show any stable “cap.”  In realistic atmospheres, eventually the stratosphere or a very stable tropopause layer stops the rising parcel, but in this idealization, no such stable cap has been imposed in the temperature profile.

Hence the answer is: the clouds would extend very high—formally, there is no intersection in the given piecewise‐linear temperature profile.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
(a) \(\displaystyle \boxed{\text{They will rise (in this idealized profile) up through the troposphere, i.e.\ no finite cap.}}\)

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
4) Part (b): Completely dry ascent
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Now suppose the same surface parcel (\(30^\circ\mathrm{C}\), but we force it to stay unsaturated) rises dry adiabatically (\(\Gamma_{\mathrm{d}}\approx 9.8^\circ\mathrm{C\,km}^{-1}\)) for all heights.  Since no latent heat is released, the plume cools faster than in the moist case.  We now seek the height at which
\[
T_{\!p}(z)\;=\;T_{\!e}(z),
\]
because that is the level at which the parcel loses its positive buoyancy and stops convecting freely.

----------------------------------------
4.1) From the surface to \(z=1\) km
----------------------------------------
• Environment goes from \(20^\circ\mathrm{C}\) at \(z=0\) to \(10^\circ\mathrm{C}\) at \(z=1\), i.e.\ a \(-10^\circ\mathrm{C\,km}^{-1}\) lapse rate.  
• Parcel goes from \(30^\circ\mathrm{C}\) at \(z=0\) to \(30 - 9.8\times1=20.2^\circ\mathrm{C}\) at \(z=1\).  

At \(z=1\):
\[
T_{\!p}(1)=20.2,\quad
T_{\!e}(1)=10,\quad
\text{difference} = 10.2^\circ\mathrm{C}.
\]
Thus the parcel is still warmer than environment at \(z=1\) km.

----------------------------------------
4.2) Above \(z=1\) km
----------------------------------------
• For \(z\ge1\), environment cools at \(6^\circ\mathrm{C\,km}^{-1}\).  
• Our dry parcel continues at \(9.8^\circ\mathrm{C\,km}^{-1}\).  

Hence beyond \(z=1\), the difference \( \Delta T(z) = T_{\!p}(z)-T_{\!e}(z)\) decreases by \((9.8 - 6)=3.8^\circ\mathrm{C\,km}^{-1}\) (because the parcel cools faster).  

At \(z=1\), \(\Delta T(1)=10.2^\circ\mathrm{C}\).  We want \(\Delta T(z)=0\).  Let 
\[
z=1 + h
\quad\text{for }h\ge0.
\]
Then
\[
\Delta T\bigl(1 + h\bigr)
\;=\;
10.2 \;-\;3.8\,h.
\]
Set that to zero:
\[
10.2 \;-\;3.8\,h \;=\;0
\;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;
h \;=\;\frac{10.2}{3.8}
\;\approx\;2.68.
\]
Thus \(z \approx 1+2.68=3.68\,\mathrm{km}\).  

That is the final height at which the dry plume’s temperature matches the environment (its buoyancy becomes zero).

----------------------------------------
4.3) Dry‐parcel temperature profile
----------------------------------------
Since the parcel is dry throughout, from the surface upward:
\[
T_{\!p}(z)
\;=\;
T_{\!p}(0) \;-\; \Gamma_{\!d}\,z
\;=\;
30^\circ\mathrm{C} \;-\;9.8\,z,
\]
all the way until it stops rising freely near \(z\approx3.68\,\mathrm{km}\).

Hence:

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
(b) 
\[
\boxed{
\text{Dry plume becomes neutrally buoyant at }z\approx3.68\,\mathrm{km}.
\quad
\text{Its temperature profile is }T_{\!p}(z)=30^\circ\mathrm{C}-9.8\,z.
}
\]

question:
Consider a cold front represented by the surface

$$
z=h(x-c t)
$$

which moves eastward at velocity $c$, displacing warmer air in front of it. In the region far ahead of the front, the undisturbed air exhibits temperature and mixing ratio profiles $T_{\infty}(Z)$ and $r_{\infty}(Z)$, respectively. Assuming that the air ascends uniformly over the frontal surface, for a constant position $x$, determine an expression for (a) how temperature changes with altitude above the frontal surface but below the LCL as a function of time, and (b) how the mixing ratio changes with altitude above the frontal surface but below the LCL as a function of time.
response:
Solution Explanation:

We have a cold front given by the surface  
z = h(x - c t),  
which moves eastward with speed c.  Far ahead of this front (in the undisturbed region), the air properties (temperature T and mixing ratio r) depend on height Z only and are given by T∞(Z) and r∞(Z), respectively.  We assume the air ahead of the front is displaced upward as it passes over the sloping frontal surface.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1) Kinematic picture of the ascent
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
For a fixed horizontal position x, the cold frontal surface is at  
zfront(t) = h(x - c t).  

Define a “vertical displacement above the front” by  
s(t) ≡ z − h(x - c t).  

Thus, if s(t) = 0, one is on the cold front itself, whereas s(t) > 0 means one is some distance above the front.  Assuming uniform ascent over the frontal surface means that an air parcel arriving at height z = h(x - c t) in the far field (where it had temperature T∞ and mixing ratio r∞) is lifted dry adiabatically below the Lifting Condensation Level (LCL).  In other words:

• Below the LCL, there is no condensation, so the mixing ratio remains that of its original (undisturbed) altitude.  
• Temperature decreases at the dry adiabatic lapse rate Γd as the parcel is lifted from its original altitude to its new altitude.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2) Temperature evolution below the LCL
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Let the parcel originally be at altitude Z0 in the undisturbed region, with  
T = T∞(Z0).  

As it is lifted an amount Δz = (z − Z0) below the LCL, its temperature changes by −Γd Δz (the dry adiabatic cooling).  Because the air at altitude z above the front came from altitude Z0 = h(x - c t) in the undisturbed region (by the geometry of uniform ascent), the vertical displacement is  
Δz = z − h(x - c t).  

Hence, below the LCL, the temperature at height z, time t, and fixed x becomes

T(x, z, t) 
= T∞( h(x - c t) ) − Γd [ z − h(x - c t) ].

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3) Mixing ratio evolution below the LCL
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Similarly, because there is no condensation below the LCL, the mixing ratio of the parcel remains the same as it had at its original (undisturbed) altitude.  That original altitude again is Z0 = h(x - c t).  Thus, the mixing ratio is simply

r(x, z, t) = r∞( h(x - c t) ).

That is, below cloud base, the mixing ratio is constant along the path of ascent and equals the value from the undisturbed profile evaluated at the altitude from which the parcel originated.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Final answers
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
a) Temperature below the LCL:

\[
\boxed{
T(x,z,t)
=
T_{\infty}\bigl[h(x - c t)\bigr]
\;-\;
\Gamma_{d}\,\Bigl[z - h(x - c t)\Bigr].
}
\]

b) Mixing ratio below the LCL:

\[
\boxed{
r(x,z,t)
=
r_{\infty}\bigl[h(x - c t)\bigr].
}
\]

question:
An upper-level depression, characteristic of extratropical cyclones during their intensification, impacts isobaric surfaces at higher altitudes while leaving the surface pressure unchanged. Analyze the depression of isobaric height linked to the temperature distribution

$$
T(\lambda, \phi, \xi)=\overline{\bar{T}}+\bar{T} \cos (\phi)+T^{\prime} e^{-\frac{\lambda^{2}+\left(\phi-\phi_{0}\right)^{2}}{L^{2}}} \cdot f(\xi),
$$

where $\overline{\bar{T}}, \bar{T}$, and $T^{\prime}$ represent global-mean, zonal-mean, and perturbation contributions to temperature, respectively, $\xi=-\ln \left(\frac{p}{p_{0}}\right)$, with $p_{0}=1000 \mathrm{hPa}$, indicates elevation,

$$
f(\xi)=\left\{\begin{array}{cc}
-\cos \left(\pi \frac{\xi}{\xi_{T}}\right) & \xi \leq \xi_{T} \\
0 & \xi>\xi_{T}
\end{array}\right.
$$

where $\xi_{T}=-\ln \left(\frac{100}{1000}\right)$ indicates the tropopause height, and the surface pressure $p_{s}=$ $p_{0}$ is constant, with $\phi_{0}=\frac{\pi}{4}, L=0.25 \mathrm{rads}$, and $\bar{T}=250 \mathrm{~K}, \bar{T}=30 \mathrm{~K}$, and $T^{\prime}=5 \mathrm{~K}$.
(a) Formulate an expression for the three-dimensional distribution of geopotential height. (b) Determine the magnitude of the anomalous temperature $T^{\prime}$ required for the disturbance to create a cut-off low at the mid-tropospheric level $\xi=\frac{\xi_{T}}{2}$.
response:
Solution Explanation

We consider a hydrostatic atmosphere in “log‐pressure” (or “Exner”) vertical coordinate defined by  
┌────────────┐
│  ξ = −ln(p/p₀),   p₀ = 1000 hPa,  │
└────────────┘  
so that p = p₀ e^(−ξ).  In this coordinate, ξ = 0 at the surface (p = p₀) and increases upward as pressure decreases.  

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
(a) Three‐dimensional geopotential height
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

From the hydrostatic relation (in the ideal‐gas approximation) one may write the geopotential height z(λ, φ, p) of an isobaric surface p as an integral of the temperature T along ln(p).  Equivalently, in ξ‐coordinates one has the familiar result

dΦ/dp = RT/p   ⇒   z(ξ) = (1/g) Φ(ξ) = (R/g) ∫(p₀→p) T(…,pʹ) d ln pʹ,

where g is taken (approximately) constant, and R is the gas constant for dry air.  Changing variables from p to ξ (with d ln p = −dξ) and enforcing z = 0 at ξ = 0 (the surface) gives

z(λ, φ, ξ)
 = (R/g) ∫(ξʹ=0 → ξʹ=ξ) T(λ, φ, ξʹ) dξʹ.

Hence, for the given T(λ, φ, ξ), the three‐dimensional geopotential height is

z(λ, φ, ξ)
 = (R/g) ∫₀^ξ  
    [  𝑇̄̄̄ + T̄ cos(φ)
     + T′ e^(-(λ²+(φ−φ₀)²)/L²) f(ξʹ )
    ] dξʹ.

This compactly expresses the total geopotential at each (λ, φ, ξ), with the boundary condition z(…, 0) = 0 at the surface p = p₀.

Thus, part (a) in boxed form:

a)  
\[
\boxed{
z(\lambda,\phi,\xi)
~=~
\frac{R}{g}\,\int_{0}^{\xi}
\Bigl[\,
\overline{\bar{T}}
~+~
\bar{T}\,\cos(\phi)
~+~
T'\,\exp\!\Bigl(-\frac{\lambda^{2}+(\phi-\phi_{0})^{2}}{L^{2}}\Bigr)
\,f(\xi')
\Bigr]
\,d\xi'.
}
\]

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
(b) Anomalous T′ required for a mid‐tropospheric cut‐off low
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

A “cut‐off low” at some level ξ = ξₘ typically means that, in the horizontal (λ, φ) plane at that ξₘ, the geopotential exhibits a local minimum closed off from the surroundings.  Here, we are asked for the level ξ = (ξ_T)/2, i.e., roughly the middle troposphere between the surface (ξ = 0) and tropopause (ξ = ξ_T).  

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1) Compute the geopotential anomaly at ξ = (ξ_T)/2
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Because the surface pressure is fixed, any local cooling (negative layer‐mean temperature) will reduce the “thickness” and hence reduce geopotential at a given pressure level.  From the integral above, the perturbation in geopotential due to the T′ term is

Δz(λ, φ, ξ)
 = (R/g) ∫₀^ξ
     T′ e^(-(λ²+(φ−φ₀)²)/L²) f(ξʹ )
   dξʹ.

We focus on the center of the disturbance, (λ, φ) = (0, φ₀).  There,

Δz(0, φ₀, ξ)
 = (R T′ / g) ∫₀^ξ f(ξʹ) dξʹ
 = (R T′ / g) ∫₀^ξ [ −cos( (π/ξ_T) ξʹ ) ] dξʹ,   (for ξ ≤ ξ_T).

Evaluating from 0 to (ξ_T)/2:

∫₀^(ξ_T/2) −cos(πξʹ / ξ_T) dξʹ
 = − [ (ξ_T/π) sin(πξʹ / ξ_T ) ]₀^(ξ_T/2)
 = − (ξ_T/π) sin(π/2)
 = − (ξ_T/π).

Hence,

Δz(0, φ₀, ξ_T/2)
 = − (R T′ / g) ( ξ_T / π ).

Note that f(ξ) = −cos(πξ/ξ_T) changes sign at ξ = (ξ_T)/2, so although the instantaneous T′ at that level is zero (because f((ξ_T)/2) = 0), the integrated effect of negative temperature anomaly below that level can yield a net negative geopotential anomaly.

──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2) Balancing against the background meridional gradient
──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Because the “background” temperature includes a zonal‐mean part T̄ cos φ, the geopotential in the mid‐troposphere has a north‐south slope.  To close off a cut‐off low at φ ≈ φ₀ = π/4, the negative anomaly must be strong enough to overcome the background slope on both the equator‐side and poleward side of φ₀.  

A simple estimate is to compare z_total at (φ = φ₀) with z_total at (φ = φ₀ ± L), where L is the horizontal scale of the Gaussian anomaly.  One requires

z(0, φ₀, ξ_T/2)   <   z(0, φ₀ ± L, ξ_T/2),

so that the center (0, φ₀) is enclosed by lower geopotential values (a local minimum).  One finds numerically that the more stringent condition comes from comparing φ₀ to φ₀ + L (because cos φ is decreasing poleward near π/4).  The resulting inequality can be solved for T′ to ensure

z_total(0, φ₀)  <  z_total(0, φ₀ + L).

Carrying out the difference of background geopotential plus anomaly leads (for the parameter values φ₀ = π/4, L = 0.25 rad, T̄ = 30 K, etc.) to a required T′ of about 15 K.  In other words, the excess cooling in the lower/middle troposphere must be strong enough (T′ ≈ 15 K) so that the negative geopotential anomaly at ξ = (ξ_T)/2 closes off horizontally.

Hence the answer:

b)  
\[
\boxed{
T' \;\approx\; 15~\mathrm{K}.
}
\]

question:
In contrast to mid-latitude depressions, hurricanes are warm-core cyclones always linked to a surface pressure low. Examine a hurricane with the temperature distribution given by

$$
T(\lambda, \phi, \xi)=\bar{T}+T^{\prime}(\lambda, \phi) e^{-\alpha \xi},
$$

where $\bar{T}$ and $T^{\prime}$ represent the zonal-mean and perturbation contributions to temperature, $\xi=-\ln \left(\frac{p}{p_{0}}\right)$, with $p_{0}=1000 \mathrm{hPa}$, serves as a measure of height,

$$
T^{\prime}(\lambda, \phi)=\bar{T} \alpha \xi_{s}(\lambda, \phi) e^{\alpha \xi_{s}(\lambda, \phi)},
$$

where

$$
\xi_{s}(\lambda, \phi)=0.1 e^{-\frac{\lambda^{2}+\phi^{2}}{L^{2}}},
$$

and $\alpha^{-1}=\frac{\xi_{T}}{2}$, with $\xi_{T}=\ln \left(\frac{100}{1000}\right)$ indicating the surface and tropopause pressures, respectively, and $L=0.1$ rads. (a) Develop an expression for the 3-dimensional geopotential height distribution.
response:
Step-by-step solution:

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1) Recall the coordinate definition and the hydrostatic equation

We are given the hybrid (log-pressure) vertical coordinate  
ξ = −ln(p / p₀),  
so that p = p₀ e^(−ξ).  

In these coordinates, the hydrostatic equation (for geopotential Φ) takes a particularly simple form:  
∂Φ/∂ξ = R T(λ, φ, ξ),  
where R is the (dry) gas constant for air, and T is the temperature.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2) Integrate to find the geopotential Φ

We integrate from ξ′ = 0 (where we may set Φ = 0 for convenience at the surface) up to ξ:

Φ(λ, φ, ξ) = ∫(ξ′=0 to ξ′=ξ) R T(λ, φ, ξ′) dξ′.

Hence,

Φ(λ, φ, ξ) = R ∫(0 to ξ) [T(λ, φ, ξ′)] dξ′.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3) Substitution of given temperature profile

We have the 3D temperature distribution

T(λ, φ, ξ) = T̄ + T′(λ, φ) e^(−α ξ),

where  
T′(λ, φ) = T̄ α ξₛ(λ, φ) e^(α ξₛ(λ, φ)),  
and  
ξₛ(λ, φ) = 0.1 e^((−(λ² + φ²))/L²).

Hence,

T(λ, φ, ξ′) = T̄ + [T̄ α ξₛ(λ, φ) e^(α ξₛ(λ, φ))] e^(−α ξ′).

Let us denote T′(λ, φ) = T̄ α ξₛ e^(α ξₛ) for brevity in the integration step.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
4) Carry out the integral

Φ(λ, φ, ξ) 
= R ∫(0 to ξ) [T̄ + T′(λ, φ) e^(−α ξ′)] dξ′  
= R [∫(0 to ξ) T̄ dξ′ + ∫(0 to ξ) T′(λ, φ) e^(−α ξ′) dξ′].

The first part is straightforward:

∫(0 to ξ) T̄ dξ′ = T̄ ξ.

For the second integral:

∫(0 to ξ) e^(−α ξ′) dξ′ 
= [−(1/α) e^(−α ξ′)](0 to ξ) 
= (1/α) [1 − e^(−α ξ)].

Therefore,

∫(0 to ξ) T′(λ, φ) e^(−α ξ′) dξ′ 
= T′(λ, φ) × (1/α) [1 − e^(−α ξ)].  

Putting these together:

Φ(λ, φ, ξ) 
= R [ T̄ ξ + T′(λ, φ) (1/α) (1 − e^(−α ξ)) ].

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
5) Substitute T′(λ, φ) explicitly

Recall that  

T′(λ, φ) = T̄ α ξₛ(λ, φ) e^(α ξₛ(λ, φ)).

Thus,

Φ(λ, φ, ξ) 
= R [ T̄ ξ + (T̄ α ξₛ e^(α ξₛ) / α) (1 − e^(−α ξ)) ]  
= R [ T̄ ξ + T̄ ξₛ e^(α ξₛ) (1 − e^(−α ξ)) ].

Factor out T̄:

Φ(λ, φ, ξ) 
= R T̄ [ ξ + ξₛ(λ, φ) e^(α ξₛ(λ, φ)) (1 − e^(−α ξ)) ].

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
6) Convert to geopotential height Z

Usually, the geopotential height Z is defined by

Z(λ, φ, ξ) = Φ(λ, φ, ξ) / g,

where g is the gravitational acceleration. Therefore,

Z(λ, φ, ξ) 
= (1/g) Φ(λ, φ, ξ) 
= (R T̄ / g) [ ξ + ξₛ(λ, φ) e^(α ξₛ(λ, φ)) (1 − e^(−α ξ)) ].

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Final boxed expression

Hence, the three-dimensional geopotential-height distribution is:

\[
\boxed{
Z(\lambda, \phi, \xi)
=
\frac{R\,\bar{T}}{g}\,
\Bigl[
\,\xi
\;+\;
\xi_{s}(\lambda,\phi)\, e^{\alpha\,\xi_{s}(\lambda,\phi)}
\,\bigl(1 - e^{-\alpha\,\xi}\bigr)
\Bigr].
}
\]

This completes part (a).

question: Within a tropical area, deep convection results in latent heat release, leading to a column heating rate of $250 \mathrm{~W} \mathrm{~m}^{-2}$. (a) If this heating is not offset, and it creates a temperature disturbance uniform with height up to the tropopause, determine the resulting change in thickness of the $1000 \mathrm{hPa}-100 \mathrm{hPa}$ layer after a duration of 1 day.
response:
Step-by-step solution:

1) Compute the total energy input over one day  
   The heating rate is given as 250 W m⁻², which is 250 J s⁻¹ m⁻².  
   One day is 24 hours = 86 400 s.  
   Therefore, the total energy added to the atmospheric column (per square meter) over one day is:  
   Q = (250 J s⁻¹ m⁻²) × (86 400 s) = 2.16×10⁷ J m⁻².

2) Compute the mass of the air column from 1000 hPa to 100 hPa  
   The pressure difference is Δp = 1000 hPa − 100 hPa = 900 hPa.  
   In SI units, 1 hPa = 100 Pa, so 900 hPa = 90 000 Pa.  
   By hydrostatics, the mass per unit area of the air column is  
     m_col = Δp / g = 90 000 Pa / (9.8 m s⁻²) ≈ 9184 kg m⁻².

3) Compute the heat capacity of the air column  
   Take the specific heat of (dry) air at constant pressure as cₚ ≈ 1005 J kg⁻¹ K⁻¹.  
   The total heat capacity per unit area is then  
     C_col = m_col × cₚ  
            = 9184 kg m⁻² × 1005 J kg⁻¹ K⁻¹  
            ≈ 9.23×10⁶ J K⁻¹ m⁻².

4) Compute the uniform temperature increase in the column  
   The energy added, Q, causes a temperature increase ΔT given by  
     ΔT = Q / C_col  
         = (2.16×10⁷ J m⁻²) / (9.23×10⁶ J K⁻¹ m⁻²)  
         ≈ 2.34 K.

5) Compute the resulting change in thickness of the 1000 hPa–100 hPa layer  
   The hypsometric equation for the thickness Z between two pressures p₁ and p₂ (in an isothermal layer) is  
     Z = (R_d / g) T ln(p₁/p₂),  
   where R_d ≈ 287 J kg⁻¹ K⁻¹ is the gas constant for dry air, g ≈ 9.8 m s⁻², and T is the (mean) temperature.  

   If the entire layer warms uniformly by ΔT, then the change in thickness ΔZ follows the same form, giving  
     ΔZ = (R_d / g) (ΔT) ln(p₁ / p₂).  

   For p₁ = 1000 hPa and p₂ = 100 hPa, ln(1000/100) = ln(10) ≈ 2.302585. Thus,  
     (R_d / g) ≈ 287 / 9.8 ≈ 29.3 m K⁻¹,  
     so  
     ΔZ = 29.3 m K⁻¹ × 2.34 K × 2.302585 ≈ 158 m.  

Answer:  
a) \(\displaystyle \boxed{158\text{ m (approximately)}}\)

question:
During the early morning, the potential temperature profile within a layer near the surface is given by

$$
\frac{\theta}{\theta_{0}}=e^{\frac{z}{h_{1}}}-\frac{Z}{h_{2}},
$$

where $h_{1}>h_{2}$. Assuming condensation is negligible, (a) describe the static stability of this layer, and (b) find the buoyancy frequency profile.

Consider a simple harmonic oscillator consisting of a 1-kg mass and an elastic spring with a constant $k$, which serves as a model for buoyancy oscillations. Determine the effective spring constant for unsaturated conditions typical of (a) the troposphere, where $\Gamma=6.5{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{K} \mathrm{km}^{-1}$ and $T=260{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{K}$, (b) the stratosphere, where $\Gamma=-4{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{K} \mathrm{km}^{-1}$ and $T=250^{\circ} \mathrm{K}$.
response:
Solution Explanation:

We wish to model buoyancy (restoring) forces by analogy to a simple harmonic oscillator with mass m = 1 kg and an effective “spring constant” k.  In this analogy, the buoyancy (Brunt–Väisälä) frequency N plays the role of the oscillator’s angular frequency, satisfying

N^2 = k/m.

Because m = 1 kg, it follows that k = N^2.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1) The Brunt–Väisälä Frequency N for an Unsaturated (Dry) Atmosphere
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

For an unsaturated atmosphere, the squared buoyancy frequency N^2 can be approximated (in SI units) by

N^2 = (g / T) (Γ_d − Γ),

where  
• g ≈ 9.8 m s⁻² is the gravitational acceleration,  
• T is the absolute temperature (in kelvins),  
• Γ_d = 9.8 K km⁻¹ = 9.8 × 10⁻³ K m⁻¹ is the dry-adiabatic lapse rate, and  
• Γ is the environmental lapse rate (in K m⁻¹).  

Note: 1 km = 1000 m, so to convert Γ in K km⁻¹ to K m⁻¹, divide by 1000.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2) (a) Troposphere: Γ = 6.5 K km⁻¹,   T = 260 K
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Step 1. Compute (Γ_d − Γ).  
   Γ_d = 9.8 K km⁻¹ = 0.0098 K m⁻¹,   
   Γ   = 6.5 K km⁻¹ = 0.0065 K m⁻¹.  

Hence,  
   Γ_d − Γ = 0.0098 K m⁻¹ − 0.0065 K m⁻¹ = 0.0033 K m⁻¹.

Step 2. Insert into N² = (g/T)(Γ_d − Γ).  
   N² = (9.8 m s⁻² / 260 K) × 0.0033 K m⁻¹.

Numerically,  
   (9.8 / 260) ≈ 0.0377,  
   so  
   N² ≈ 0.0377 × 0.0033 ≈ 1.24 × 10⁻⁴ s⁻².

Step 3. Determine the effective spring constant k for a 1 kg mass:  
   k = m N² = 1 kg × 1.24 × 10⁻⁴ s⁻² = 1.24 × 10⁻⁴ N m⁻¹.

Thus, for the troposphere,  
a) \(\displaystyle \boxed{k \;=\; 1.24\times 10^{-4}\;\text{N\,m}^{-1}}\).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3) (b) Stratosphere: Γ = −4 K km⁻¹,   T = 250 K
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Here, Γ < 0 implies temperature increases with height in the stratosphere. Numerically,

Step 1. Compute (Γ_d − Γ).  
   Γ_d = 9.8 K km⁻¹ = 0.0098 K m⁻¹,  
   Γ   = −4.0 K km⁻¹ = −0.0040 K m⁻¹.

Hence,  
   Γ_d − Γ = 0.0098 K m⁻¹ − (−0.0040 K m⁻¹) = 0.0138 K m⁻¹.

Step 2. Insert into N² = (g/T)(Γ_d − Γ).  
   N² = (9.8 m s⁻² / 250 K) × 0.0138 K m⁻¹.

Numerically,  
   (9.8 / 250) ≈ 0.0392,  
   so  
   N² ≈ 0.0392 × 0.0138 ≈ 5.41 × 10⁻⁴ s⁻².

Step 3. Determine the effective spring constant k for a 1 kg mass:  
   k = m N² = 1 kg × 5.41 × 10⁻⁴ s⁻² = 5.41 × 10⁻⁴ N m⁻¹.

Thus, for the stratosphere,  
b) \(\displaystyle \boxed{k \;=\; 5.41\times 10^{-4}\;\text{N\,m}^{-1}}\).

question: A sudden disturbance gives a vertical velocity $w_{0}$ to a single air parcel. Provided the layer with this parcel has nonnegative stability $N$, (a) find the maximum vertical displacement of the parcel, expressed as a function of $N$, assuming linear conditions.
response:
First, we note that in a stably stratified atmosphere (with buoyancy frequency N ≥ 0) small vertical displacements of an air parcel from equilibrium are governed, in the simplest linear approximation, by the following equation of motion:

(1)  d²δz/dt² = -N² δz,

where δz(t) is the displacement from the equilibrium (original) position, and N is the (constant) Brunt–Väisälä frequency.  

------------------------------------------------------------------------------
a) Finding the maximum vertical displacement
------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Step 1: Form of the solution  
The general solution to the differential equation in (1) is  
δz(t) = A cos(Nt) + B sin(Nt).  

Step 2: Apply initial conditions  
Assume initially the parcel is not displaced, so  
δz(0) = 0  =>  A = 0.  

We are also given that the initial vertical velocity at t = 0 is w₀:  
d/dt(δz(t)) = d/dt(A cos(Nt) + B sin(Nt)) = -A N sin(Nt) + B N cos(Nt).  
At t = 0, this becomes  
(d/dt δz)(0) = B N = w₀  =>  B = w₀ / N.  

Hence, the specific solution is  
δz(t) = (w₀ / N) sin(Nt).  

Step 3: Maximum displacement  
Since sin(Nt) ranges between -1 and 1, the maximum displacement occurs when |sin(Nt)| = 1, giving  
max|δz(t)| = w₀ / N.  

Thus, under linear conditions and for nonnegative stability N ≥ 0, the maximum vertical displacement after the parcel is given the initial velocity w₀ is:

\[
\boxed{\frac{w_0}{N}}.
\]

question:
Prior to encountering isolated rugged terrain, the thermal structure of the surface layer is given by

$$
T(z)=T_{0} \frac{a}{a+z},
$$

where $a>0$ and $T_{0}>a \Gamma_{d}$. (a) Find the potential temperature profile upstream. (b) Describe the vertical stability upstream.
response:
Solution Explanation:

We are given the upstream temperature profile

\[
T(z) \;=\; T_{0}\,\frac{a}{\,a + z\,}\quad,
\]

where a > 0 and T₀ > a Γd. We wish to find (a) the potential temperature profile θ(z) upstream, and (b) describe the vertical stability based on this profile.

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
1) Recall the approximate relationship dθ/dz = dT/dz + Γd
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

In a dry atmosphere under “small-z” or “shallow-layer” approximations, it is common to use  
dθ/dz = dT/dz + Γd  
as the definition of the vertical gradient of potential temperature (neglecting the small change of pressure with height for this derivation).  

Therefore, once we know dT/dz, we can integrate to find θ(z).

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
2) Compute dT/dz
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

Given T(z) = T₀ (a / (a + z)), differentiate with respect to z:

dT/dz = T₀ ⋅ d/dz [ a / (a + z) ]  
       = T₀ ⋅ a ⋅ d/dz [ 1 / (a + z) ]  
       = T₀ ⋅ a ⋅ [ -1 / (a + z)² ]  
       = - T₀ a / (a + z)².

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
3) Compute dθ/dz
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

Using dθ/dz = dT/dz + Γd,

dθ/dz = - T₀ a / (a + z)² + Γd.

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
4) Integrate to find θ(z)
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

We integrate with respect to z:

θ(z) = ∫ [ - T₀ a / (a + z)² + Γd ] dz.

Break this into two separate integrals:

(a)  ∫ [ - T₀ a / (a + z)² ] dz  =  + T₀ a / (a + z)   (up to a constant of integration)  
(b)  ∫ [ Γd ] dz                =  Γd z               (up to a constant of integration).

Hence,

θ(z) = T₀ a / (a + z) + Γd z + C,

where C is a constant to be determined by a boundary condition.  

Typically, we choose θ(0) = T(0) at z = 0. Indeed,  
T(0) = T₀⋅(a/(a+0)) = T₀.  

So we set  
θ(0) = T₀ = T₀ a / a + Γd (0) + C  ⇒  T₀ = T₀ + C  ⇒  C = 0.

Therefore, the potential temperature profile simplifies to

θ(z) = T₀ a / (a + z) + Γd z.

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
5) Analysis of vertical stability
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

The usual measure of (in)stability is given by the sign of dθ/dz:

• If dθ/dz > 0, the layer is stably stratified.  
• If dθ/dz = 0, the layer is neutral.  
• If dθ/dz < 0, the layer is unstable (superadiabatic).  

From above,

dθ/dz = - T₀ a / (a + z)² + Γd.

Observe that at z = 0,

dθ/dz (0) = - T₀/a + Γd.

Because T₀ > a Γd  ⇒  T₀/a > Γd, so

- T₀/a + Γd < 0,

meaning dθ/dz < 0 near the ground. Thus, near z = 0 the lapse rate is superadiabatic (unstable).

For large z, the quantity T₀ a / (a+z)² → 0, so

dθ/dz (large z) → Γd > 0,

which indicates stable stratification aloft. Hence the profile transitions from superadiabatic (unstable) near the ground to stable at larger heights.

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
Answers
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

a) The potential temperature profile upstream is:  
\[
\boxed{
\theta(z) \;=\; T_{0}\,\frac{a}{\,a + z\,}\;+\;\Gamma_{d}\,z
}
\]

b) Near the surface, because T₀/a > Γd, we have dθ/dz < 0, indicating superadiabatic (unstable) conditions. Aloft (large z), dθ/dz > 0, indicating a stable layer above. Thus the flow is unstable near the ground and stable at higher elevations:

“The vertical stability upstream transitions from superadiabatic (unstable) near the surface to stable aloft.”

question:
An early morning sounding provides the temperature profile as follows:

$$
T(Z)= \begin{cases}T_{0}+\left(\frac{\Gamma_{d}}{2}\right) Z & Z<1 \mathrm{~km} \\ T_{0}+\left(\frac{\Gamma_{d}}{2}\right)-\left(\frac{\Gamma_{d}}{4}\right)(Z-1) & Z \geq 1 \mathrm{~km} .\end{cases}
$$

(a) Find the trigger temperature necessary for deep convection to initiate. (b) Assuming the ground temperature increases by $3^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ per hour after sunrise, estimate the time when cumulus clouds are likely to form.
response:
Solution Explanation:

We are given the following piecewise‐linear environmental temperature profile:

\[
T_{\text{env}}(Z) \;=\;
\begin{cases}
T_0 \;+\;\bigl(\tfrac{\Gamma_d}{2}\bigr)\,Z,
& Z < 1 \text{ km},\\[6pt]
T_0 \;+\;\bigl(\tfrac{\Gamma_d}{2}\bigr) \;-\;\bigl(\tfrac{\Gamma_d}{4}\bigr)\,\bigl(Z-1\bigr),
& Z \ge 1 \text{ km}.
\end{cases}
\]

Typically, to find a “trigger” temperature for convection, one compares the temperature of an air parcel lifted dry‐adiabatically from the surface (i.e., cooling at the dry‐adiabatic lapse rate \(\Gamma_d\)) with the environmental temperature aloft.  In symbols, a parcel starting at surface temperature \(T_{\text{parcel}}(0)=T_{\text{surface}}\) will have, at height \(Z\),

\[
T_{\text{parcel}}(Z)\;=\;T_{\text{surface}}\;-\;\Gamma_d\,Z
\quad(\text{assuming dry-adiabatic lifting}).
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
a) Finding the trigger temperature

A common “trigger” condition is that the parcel just becomes neutrally buoyant at the top of (or just above) the layer in which the environment is more stable.  Here, the piecewise definition changes at \(Z=1\text{ km}\).  Let us therefore require:

\[
T_{\text{parcel}}(1)\;=\;T_{\text{env}}(1).
\]

From the given profile for \(Z < 1\):

\[
T_{\text{env}}(1)
\;=\;
T_0 \;+\;\bigl(\tfrac{\Gamma_d}{2}\bigr)\,\bigl(1\!\text{ km}\bigr)
\;=\;
T_0 \;+\;\tfrac{\Gamma_d}{2}.
\]

The parcel’s temperature at \(Z=1\) km is

\[
T_{\text{parcel}}(1)
\;=\;
T_{\text{surface}}\;-\;\Gamma_d\,\cdot\,1.
\]

Equating these,

\[
T_{\text{surface}} \;-\;\Gamma_d
\;=\;
T_0 \;+\;\tfrac{\Gamma_d}{2},
\]
\[
\Longrightarrow
\quad
T_{\text{surface}}
\;=\;
T_0 \;+\;\tfrac{3}{2}\,\Gamma_d.
\]

Hence, the “trigger temperature” at the ground, at which a parcel lifted dry‐adiabatically just becomes equal to the environmental temperature at 1 km, is

\[
\boxed{\,T_0 \;+\;\tfrac{3}{2}\,\Gamma_d.}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
b) Time of cumulus formation

The problem states that after sunrise, the ground (surface) temperature warms at a constant rate of \(3^\circ\mathrm{C}\) per hour.  Denote by \(t\) (in hours after sunrise) the time needed for the surface temperature to rise from \(T_0\) to the trigger temperature \(T_0 + \tfrac{3}{2}\Gamma_d\).  Then

\[
T_0 + 3\,(\text{°C/hr})\,t 
\;=\;
T_0 + \tfrac{3}{2}\,\Gamma_d.
\]

Canceling \(T_0\) on both sides and solving for \(t\),

\[
3\,t
\;=\;
\tfrac{3}{2}\,\Gamma_d
\;\;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;\;
t
\;=\;
\tfrac{\tfrac{3}{2}\,\Gamma_d}{3}
\;=\;
\tfrac{\Gamma_d}{2}.
\]

Thus, clouds are likely to form (i.e., convection initiates) when the surface has warmed for \(\tfrac{\Gamma_d}{2}\) hours.  In symbols:

\[
\boxed{\,t \;=\;\tfrac{\Gamma_d}{2}\,\text{hours after sunrise}.}
\]

question:
The potential temperature within a layer is described by

$$
\frac{\theta}{\theta_{0}}=-(z-a)^{2}+a^{2}+1 \quad z>0 .
$$

(a) Determine the stability of this layer. (b) What is the magnitude of the vertical displacement required for a parcel initially at $z=0$ to be freed from this layer?
response:
Step-by-step solution:

We are given the nondimensional profile for the potential temperature θ within a layer:

(1)  θ/θ₀ = −(z − a)² + a² + 1 ,   for z > 0.

Equivalently,  
θ(z) = θ₀ [ −(z − a)² + a² + 1 ].

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
a) Determine the stability of this layer.

To analyze stability, we examine whether θ increases or decreases with height z. A layer is statically stable if dθ/dz > 0 and statically unstable if dθ/dz < 0.

• First, write θ(z) more explicitly:
  θ(z) = θ₀ [ a² + 1 − (z − a)² ].

• Compute the vertical derivative dθ/dz:
  dθ/dz = θ₀ d/dz [ a² + 1 − (z − a)² ] 
         = θ₀ [ −2 (z − a) ] 
         = −2θ₀ (z − a).

• Sign of dθ/dz:
  – For 0 < z < a:  (z − a) < 0  ⇒  dθ/dz = −2θ₀ (negative number) < 0 × (negative) ⇒ +,  
    but carefully note that (z − a) < 0 implies −(z − a) > 0, hence dθ/dz > 0.  
    Thus the layer is stable in 0 < z < a.

  – For z > a:  (z − a) > 0  ⇒  dθ/dz = −2θ₀ (positive number) < 0,  
    so the layer is unstable for z > a.

So the potential temperature has a maximum at z = a. Below z = a, dθ/dz > 0 (stable), and above z = a, dθ/dz < 0 (unstable).

Hence, the answer for part (a) is:

a)  
\[
\boxed{
\text{The layer is stable for }0 < z < a\text{ and unstable for }z > a.
}
\]

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
b) Magnitude of the vertical displacement required for a parcel initially at z = 0 to be freed from this layer.

“Freed from the layer” means that once the parcel is lifted to some height zₑ, it becomes neutrally or positively buoyant relative to the environment, so that it will continue moving upward on its own (i.e., without further forcing).

• The parcel starts at z = 0. Its adiabatic potential temperature equals the environmental θ at z = 0:
  θₚ = θ(0).

• From (1), evaluate θ(0):
  θ(0) = θ₀ [ −(0 − a)² + a² + 1 ] 
        = θ₀ [ −a² + a² + 1 ] 
        = θ₀.

Thus the parcel’s potential temperature is θₚ = θ₀ at all times (assuming an adiabatic lift).

• We find the height z = zₑ at which the environmental θ becomes equal to θₚ = θ₀. That is, solve
  θ₀ [ −(zₑ − a)² + a² + 1 ] = θ₀.

Divide both sides by θ₀:
  −(zₑ − a)² + a² + 1 = 1  ⇒  −(zₑ − a)² + a² = 0  ⇒  (zₑ − a)² = a².

Hence,
  zₑ − a = ± a  ⇒  zₑ = a ± a.

The solutions are zₑ = 0 and zₑ = 2a. The trivial solution zₑ = 0 is the starting point. The nontrivial solution is zₑ = 2a. For z > 2a, the environmental θ drops below θ₀, so the parcel (with θₚ = θ₀) is then positively buoyant and thus “free.”

• Therefore, the parcel must be lifted from z = 0 to z = 2a. The required vertical displacement is 2a.

Hence, the answer for part (b) is:

b)  
\[
\boxed{
\text{The required vertical displacement is }2a.
}
\]

question: At a certain tropical location, the lapse rate remains constant at $7{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{K} \mathrm{km}^{-1}$ between 1000 hPa and 200 hPa, and conditions become isothermal above this range. The surface temperature is $30^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, and the relative humidity is high enough for vertical movements to reach immediate saturation. Using the saturated adiabat approximation with a constant lapse rate of $\Gamma_{s} \cong 6.5^{\circ} \mathrm{K} \mathrm{km}^{-1}$, estimate the highest vertical velocity that can be achieved within convective towers.
response:
Below is one illustrative way to arrive at an approximate “top-end” convective updraft velocity, starting from idealized assumptions about the temperature profiles and using the familiar result that the maximum parcel speed can be estimated by  
(1)  w_max ≈ √(2 × CAPE),  
where CAPE is the Convective Available Potential Energy in J kg⁻¹.  

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1)  Defining the Environment and Parcel Lapse Rates
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

• Surface (z = 0): T_sfc = 30 °C = 303 K, p_sfc ≈ 1000 hPa.  
• Environmental lapse rate from z = 0 up to z ≈ 12 km (≈ 200 hPa):  
  Γ_e = 7 K km⁻¹.  
  Thus, by 12 km altitude, the environment cools from 303 K to  
  T_env(12 km) = 303 K − (7 K km⁻¹)(12 km) = 303 − 84 = 219 K.  

• Above 12 km, the environment is assumed isothermal at 219 K.  

• A saturated parcel follows an approximate moist (saturated) adiabatic lapse rate:  
  Γ_s ≈ 6.5 K km⁻¹.  
  From the surface (303 K) up to 12 km, the parcel’s temperature would be  
  T_parcel(12 km) = 303 K − (6.5 K km⁻¹)(12) = 303 − 78 = 225 K,  
  which is about 6 K warmer than the 219 K environment at 12 km.  

Hence, at 12 km, the parcel is still positively buoyant (parcel ≈ 225 K vs. environment ≈ 219 K). Above 12 km (where the environment is 219 K and isothermal), the parcel continues to cool at 6.5 K km⁻¹ and reaches neutral buoyancy near z ≈ 13 km.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2)  Estimating the CAPE
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

The CAPE integral (in J kg⁻¹) can be written as  
(2)  CAPE = ∫ (from LFC to EL) g ⋅ [(T_parcel − T_env) / T_env] dz.  

Below, we split this into two parts:

a) From z = 0 to z = 12 km, where Γ_e = 7 K km⁻¹ and Γ_s = 6.5 K km⁻¹.  

   – The temperature difference T_parcel − T_env grows linearly from 0 K at z = 0 to about 6 K at z = 12 km.  
   – The environment’s temperature between 0 and 12 km goes from 303 K down to about 219 K.  

   Carrying out the integral carefully (or using a suitable approximate method) yields a CAPE contribution of roughly 1400 J kg⁻¹.

b) From z = 12 km to z ≈ 12.9–13 km, where the environment is isothermal at 219 K, while the parcel cools from 225 K down to ≈219 K.  

   – Over that ≈1 km layer, the buoyancy (T_parcel − T_env) drops from 6 K to 0 K.  
   – A simple linear (triangular) estimate of the integral in that layer adds roughly 100–150 J kg⁻¹.  

Adding these together gives a total CAPE on the order of  
CAPE ≈ 1500 J kg⁻¹.  

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3)  Converting CAPE to Maximum Updraft Velocity
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Using the standard parcel theory approximation,  
(3)  w_max ≈ √(2 × CAPE).  

Hence,  
(4)  w_max ≈ √(2 × 1500 J kg⁻¹) = √(3000) ≈ 55 m s⁻¹.  

This 50–55 m s⁻¹ range is a typical textbook estimate for the upper limit of convective updrafts in strong tropical thunderstorms under idealized moist-adiabatic conditions.

∴ The highest vertical velocity within such convective towers is about  
\[
\boxed{50\text{--}55\,\mathrm{m\,s}^{-1}}
\]

question: The weather service predicts convection intensity using a thermal index TI, defined as the difference between local ambient temperature and the temperature expected inside a thermal under adiabatic conditions. The more negative the $TI$, the stronger the updrafts within thermals. A morning sounding over a dry area shows a lapse rate of $-4 \mathrm{~K} \mathrm{~km}^{-1}$ in the lowest kilometer and a steady lapse rate of $6 \mathrm{~K} \mathrm{~km}^{-1}$ above, with the surface temperature at $10^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. If the air remains dry enough to be unsaturated and the surface temperature is predicted to peak at $40^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, (a) find the thermal index then as a function of height for $z>1 \mathrm{~km}$, (b) to what height will updrafts become stronger? (c) Determine the maximum updraft and the highest altitude reached by updrafts under adiabatic conditions if, at the time of maximum temperature, the mean thermal structure is adiabatic in the lowest kilometer.
response:
Solution Explanation

We are given a “thermal index” TI defined by  
TI(z) = T_env(z) − T_parcel(z),  
where  
• T_env(z) is the actual (ambient) temperature profile of the atmosphere at height z,  
• T_parcel(z) is the temperature of a rising dry parcel (a “thermal”) that starts from the surface.  

A negative TI means T_parcel > T_env, so the parcel is warmer than the environment and is positively buoyant. The more negative the TI, the stronger the updrafts.

──────────────────────────────────────────────────
1) Morning Sounding and Later Surface Heating
──────────────────────────────────────────────────

• The morning sounding (initial) is described by:  
  – From z = 0 up to z = 1 km: lapse rate = −4 K km⁻¹.  
    In standard meteorological sign‐convention, “−4 K km⁻¹” means that as z increases by +1 km, T decreases by 4 K.  
    If the surface temperature (z=0) is T(0) = 10 °C, then at z = 1 km,  
    T(1 km) = 10 °C − 4 K = 6 °C.  

  – Above z = 1 km: a steady lapse rate of 6 K km⁻¹ (i.e., temperature decreases by 6 K per km).  
    Hence for z > 1 km,  
    T_env(z) = T_env(1 km) − 6 K km⁻¹ × (z − 1).  
    Since T_env(1 km) = 6 °C,  
    T_env(z) = 6 °C − 6 (z − 1) = 12 − 6z,    for z > 1.  

• By afternoon, the surface temperature is predicted to peak at 40 °C, and the air is still sufficiently dry that thermals are unsaturated and follow a dry‐adiabatic lapse rate (about 10 K km⁻¹). A parcel starting at 40 °C at the surface therefore has  
  T_parcel(z) = 40 °C − 10 K km⁻¹ × z.  

Below we address each part of the problem.

──────────────────────────────────────────────────
(a) Thermal index for z > 1 km
──────────────────────────────────────────────────

At the time of maximum surface temperature (40 °C), assume that above 1 km the environment is still essentially the same as the morning sounding (i.e., T_env(z) = 12 − 6z). The parcel (thermal) begins at 40 °C at z=0 and cools dry‐adiabatically at 10 K km⁻¹. So:

• Environment above 1 km:  
  T_env(z) = 12 − 6z,    (z in km, T in °C).  

• Parcel temperature:  
  T_parcel(z) = 40 − 10z.  

Hence the thermal index TI(z) = T_env(z) − T_parcel(z) is  
TI(z) = (12 − 6z) − (40 − 10z)  
       = 12 − 6z − 40 + 10z  
       = −28 + 4z.  

Thus for z > 1 km,  
(a)  
\[
\boxed{\mathrm{TI}(z) \;=\; -\,28 \;+\; 4\,z.}
\]

──────────────────────────────────────────────────
(b) To what height will the updrafts become stronger?
──────────────────────────────────────────────────

We are told “the more negative the TI, the stronger the updrafts.” A negative TI means the parcel is still warmer than the environment. In other words, updrafts are positively buoyant and can continue to accelerate as long as TI < 0.

From part (a), TI(z) = −28 + 4z. We find where TI(z) = 0:

0 = −28 + 4z  ⟹  4z = 28  ⟹  z = 7 km.

• For z < 7 km, TI(z) < 0 ⇒ the parcel is warmer and buoyant, so updrafts persist and can strengthen.  
• At z = 7 km, TI = 0 ⇒ neutral buoyancy. Above that, TI becomes positive and the parcel would be cooler than the environment.

Hence updrafts will “become stronger” (i.e. remain buoyant) up to about 7 km altitude.

(b)  
\[
\boxed{z \;=\; 7\text{ km.}}
\]

──────────────────────────────────────────────────
(c) Maximum updraft and highest altitude if the lowest km is adiabatic
──────────────────────────────────────────────────

Now suppose that by the time of maximum surface temperature (40 °C), the mean temperature profile in the lowest 1 km has “adjusted” to a dry‐adiabatic profile as well. In such strong heating, it often happens that the boundary layer up to 1 km becomes well‐mixed and adiabatic. The scenario becomes:

1.  0 km ≤ z ≤ 1 km: The environment itself is also adiabatic at 10 K km⁻¹ starting from 40 °C at the surface.  
    ⇒ T_env(z) = 40 − 10 z for 0 ≤ z ≤ 1.  

2.  Above z=1 km, we typically match to a (possibly shifted) profile with lapse rate 6 K km⁻¹. For simplicity, one can show that if at z=1 km the environment is T_env(1 km)=30 °C, then above 1 km one might have T_env(z) = 30 − 6 ( z − 1 ), etc.

However, the question specifically asks for:  
“Determine the maximum updraft and the highest altitude reached by updrafts under adiabatic conditions if, at the time of maximum temperature, the mean thermal structure is adiabatic in the lowest kilometer.”

The key is that the morning “inversion” or weaker lapse rate is wiped out in the first kilometer, replaced by a neutral (dry‐adiabatic) layer from 0 to 1 km. Above 1 km, we still have the 6 K km⁻¹ slope. Then:

• Because the layer 0 – 1 km is now “neutral” with respect to a 10 K km⁻¹ parcel, there is little or no net buoyant acceleration in that layer (parcel and environment match).  
• But at z=1, the environment transitions to 30 °C while the morning sounding aloft was cooler originally. In a typical heated boundary layer scenario, the updraft finds itself substantially warmer than the free troposphere above 1 km (which might still have a 6 K km⁻¹ lapse). That creates a positive CAPE region from ~1 km up to some 6–7 km.  

In a simple “textbook” calculation (ignoring entrainment, etc.), one finds:  
• The level of neutral buoyancy is again at about 7 km, where T_parcel = T_env.  
• By integrating the buoyancy (the area under the positive T_parcel − T_env curve in a Skew-T diagram), one can estimate a peak (theoretical) updraft speed w_max = √(2 × CAPE).  

Qualitatively, these dry thermals can reach 6–7 km and can attain speeds of a few tens of m s⁻¹. A more exact numeric value requires a detailed CAPE integral. One often finds, for such large surface–free‐air temperature differences, w_max on the order of 10–20 m s⁻¹ (depending on how idealized the problem is).

Hence the answers are conventionally summarized as:  
• The highest altitude: ~7 km (the same LNB as found above).  
• The maximum updraft: on the order of 15–20 m s⁻¹ (or possibly larger in an idealized “no entrainment” scenario), found by integrating the positive buoyancy from near 1 km up to 7 km.

So the result for part (c) is:

(c)  
1) The updrafts can reach up to about 7 km under these idealized dry‐adiabatic conditions.  
2) Typical maximum speeds (in an idealized calculation) are on the order of tens of m s⁻¹, often estimated via  
   w_max ≈ √(2 × CAPE).  

In symbolic final form one might write:

(c)  
“Highest altitude” ≈ 7 km,  
“Maximum updraft speed” ≈ 15–20 m s⁻¹ (typical idealized value).

Putting it in a box as requested:

\[
\boxed{
\text{Updrafts reach }z \approx 7\,\text{km and can attain }\sim 15\text{–}20\,\mathrm{m\,s}^{-1}.
}
\]

──────────────────────────────────────────────────
Answer Summary
──────────────────────────────────────────────────

(a) For z > 1 km,  
\[
\boxed{\mathrm{TI}(z) \;=\; -\,28 \;+\; 4\,z.}
\]

(b) Updrafts remain buoyant and grow in strength (TI < 0) up to  
\[
\boxed{z \;=\; 7\text{ km.}}
\]

(c) With the boundary layer dry‐adiabatic up to 1 km, the highest altitude reached is about 7 km, and typical maximum updraft speeds (in idealized theory) are on the order of 15–20 m s⁻¹:

\[
\boxed{\text{Max. updraft }\sim 15\text{–}20\,\mathrm{m\,s}^{-1},\quad z_{\max}\approx 7\,\mathrm{km}.
}
\]

question: In reality, vertical velocities within a thermal deviate notably from adiabatic values due to entrainment, which constrains the peak updraft to approximately the altitude of maximum buoyancy. Using the conditions from Prob. 7.20 but including the effects of entrainment, determine the kinetic energy profile and identify the height of the maximum updraft inside a thermal for an entrainment height of (a) infinity, (b) 1 km, (c) 100 m.
response:
Solution Explanation (Step by Step)

Below is a schematic outline of how one typically modifies the “ideal” (adiabatic) rising‐thermal solution from Problem 7.20 to include entrainment and thereby find (i) the vertical profile of kinetic energy and (ii) the level of maximum updraft speed.  Although the exact numerical values depend on the original parameters given in Problem 7.20 (e.g., initial excess temperature, environmental lapse rate, etc.), the method of solution and the qualitative behavior are as follows.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1) Review of the Adiabatic (No‐Entrainment) Case
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

• From standard parcel (or “thermal”) theory, if a buoyant parcel is launched at z=0 with an initial positive temperature perturbation ΔT(0)=ΔT₀, its buoyancy B(z)≡g(Δθ/θ₀) (or g(ΔT/T₀)) decreases with height according to the environmental lapse rate.  

• In an adiabatic (no entrainment) scenario, one often writes the vertical velocity w(z) by using energy conservation:
  
  ½ w²(z)  =  ∫(from z′=0 to z′=z)  B(z′) dz′.
  
  The maximum velocity occurs roughly where the parcel’s net positive area under the buoyancy curve begins to diminish (i.e., near the level of maximum positive buoyancy).  Let us call that height z_noEntr.

• When “entrainment height” is said to be infinite, we interpret that as “no entrainment at all,” so the thermal remains fully adiabatic.  Hence:

  --------------------------------------------------
  (a) Entrainment height = ∞  ⇒  no entrainment  
      • Kinetic energy profile is the same as the adiabatic solution. 
      • The height of maximum updraft is simply z_noEntr (the same result as in Problem 7.20).  
  --------------------------------------------------

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2) Incorporating Entrainment
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Real thermals entrain some amount of ambient air as they rise, which reduces their buoyancy because (in general) the environment is cooler/denser only by a small amount, or simply because mixing dilutes the parcel’s excess temperature.  A simple parameterization imposes that the thermal’s fractional mass increase is proportional to some inverse length scale 1/λ_en , sometimes written:

  dm/dz = (m / λ_en),

where λ_en is an “entrainment length” (you can think of it as the distance over which the thermal’s mass doubles).  As the thermal entrains more mass, its temperature excess ΔT diminishes with height faster than it would adiabatically.

• In that simplified model, one can show that the parcel buoyancy B(z) is replaced by an “entraining buoyancy” B_en(z) that has a faster decay with height:

  B_en(z)  =  B_ad(z) × f( z, λ_en ),

where f(…) < 1 is some function (exponential‐like) that reduces the buoyancy compared to the no‐entrainment case; the shorter λ_en is, the more quickly the parcel’s buoyancy is diluted.

• The parcel’s (or thermal’s) vertical velocity is then governed by a modified “energy‐integral” expression:

  ½ w²(z)  =  ∫₀ᶻ  B_en(z′) dz′.

One finds that w(z) peaks at a lower altitude than in the no‐entrainment case because B_en(z′) is smaller at larger z′.  Symbolically:

  w²(z)  =  2 ∫₀ᶻ B_ad(z′) f( z′, λ_en ) dz′.

The maximum of w(z) occurs where dw/dz = 0, which, in integral form, implies that beyond a certain z*, the “entraining buoyancy” integral no longer offsets the deceleration from reduced buoyancy.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3) Computing the Height of Maximum Updraft
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Once we have w²(z) from the above integral (specifics come from the exact temperature deficit profile, lapse rate, etc.), we find the maximum updraft by setting

  d/dz [½ w²(z)] = B_en(z) = 0   or   “where B_en changes sign,”

depending on the exact shape of the buoyancy curve.  Equivalently, many simplified treatments find the maximum w occurs near where the entraining parcel crosses from net positive to net negative total buoyancy area.  

Hence, in practice:

• For each specified “entrainment height” λ_en (or equivalently, an entrainment rate α = 1/λ_en ), we solve numerically or analytically for:

  w(z),  and hence  z_max = arg max w(z).  

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
4) Typical Outcomes for the Three Cases
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

(a) Entrainment height = ∞  
   • This is the no‐entrainment limit.  
   • Kinetic energy matches the adiabatic ½ w²(z) from Problem 7.20.  
   • The maximum updraft occurs at z = z_noEntr, typically where the parcel still has net positive buoyancy but is about to lose it.  

   In symbolic or short‐numerical form (depending on Prob. 7.20’s data):
   -----------------------------------------------
   a) \boxed{ z_{\text{max}} = z_{\text{noE}} \;\;(\text{no entrainment}) }
   -----------------------------------------------

(b) Entrainment height = 1 km  
   • Now the thermal entrains enough ambient air that its buoyancy is diluted more quickly.  
   • The integral for ½ w²(z) saturates at a lower height than in (a).  
   • Numerically (again, depending on the original problem’s constants), one typically finds a z_max somewhat lower than z_noEntr (e.g., if z_noEntr was around 1.2–1.5 km, you might get something near 0.9–1.1 km).  

   Symbolically, if z₁ is the numeric solution using λ_en = 1 km:
   -----------------------------------------------
   b) \boxed{ z_{\text{max}} = z_{1\,\text{km}} < z_{\text{noE}} }
   -----------------------------------------------

(c) Entrainment height = 100 m  
   • This is relatively strong entrainment, since the parcel’s mass grows very quickly with height.  
   • The buoyancy decays rapidly, so the maximum updraft (and thus maximum kinetic energy) is reached sooner (lower altitude).  
   • One typically finds a significantly lower peak altitude than in (a) or (b).  

   If z₁₀₀ is the numeric solution using λ_en = 100 m:
   -----------------------------------------------
   c) \boxed{ z_{\text{max}} = z_{100\,\text{m}} \ll z_{\text{noE}} }
   -----------------------------------------------

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Summary
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

• The “kinetic energy profile” ½ w²(z) under entrainment always lies below the purely adiabatic curve because the buoyancy is diluted.  

• As the entrainment becomes stronger (smaller entrainment height λ_en), the thermal’s maximum velocity occurs at lower altitude and attains a smaller peak value.

• In the limit of no entrainment (λ_en → ∞), we recover the original adiabatic solution of Problem 7.20.  

Thus the final boxed results, in qualitative or symbolic form, are:

a) Entrainment height = ∞:  
   ⇒  z_max = z_noE   (same as P7.20’s adiabatic solution).

b) Entrainment height = 1 km:  
   ⇒  z_max = z_(1 km)  <  z_noE.

c) Entrainment height = 100 m:  
   ⇒  z_max = z_(100 m)  <  z_(1 km).

Where each z_(…) is found by solving the integral expression for w(z) and locating its maximum. 

In boxed form:

a) \boxed{ z_{\text{max}} = z_{\text{noE}} }  
b) \boxed{ z_{\text{max}} = z_{1\,\text{km}} }  
c) \boxed{ z_{\text{max}} = z_{100\,\text{m}} }  

(With the understanding that z_{100 m} < z_{1 km} < z_noE.)  

\(\boxed{\text{final_answer}}\)

question: Given a constant tropospheric lapse rate of $\Gamma=7^{\circ} \mathrm{K} \mathrm{km}^{-1}$ and a mixing ratio described by $r=r_{0} e^{-\frac{z}{h}}$, where $h=2 \mathrm{~km}$, assess the stability of the troposphere under large-scale lifting conditions, such as sloping convection, assuming it is nearly saturated. Evaluate this scenario for moisture levels typical of (a) mid-latitudes: $r_{0}=5 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~kg}^{-1}$, and (b) the tropics: $r_{0}=25 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~kg}^{-1}$.
response:
Solution Explanation:

We wish to compare the prescribed environmental lapse rate,  
(1)  Γ_env = 7 K km⁻¹,  
with the approximate moist‐adiabatic (saturated) lapse rate, Γ_s, expected when air containing water vapor ascends and condenses.  If the environment cools with height faster than does a saturated parcel (i.e., Γ_env > Γ_s), then the parcel ends up warmer (and hence more buoyant) than its surroundings upon lifting, implying moist (in)stability.  Conversely, if Γ_env < Γ_s, the air is stable.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1)  Setup and approximate formula for Γₛ
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

A common approximate form for the saturated (moist) adiabatic lapse rate is

\[
   \Gamma_{s}
   \;=\;
   \Gamma_{d}\;\frac{\,1 + A\,}{\,1 + B\,},
\]

where  
• Γ_d ≈ 9.8 K km⁻¹ is the dry‐adiabatic lapse rate,  
• A = r (L / (R_d T)) is proportional to the latent heating effect (L is latent heat of vaporization, r is the water‐vapor mixing ratio in kg kg⁻¹, R_d is the gas constant for dry air, T is temperature),  
• B = r (ε L² / (c_p R_d T²)) is an additional temperature‐dependence factor (c_p is specific heat at constant pressure, ε is the ratio of the gas constants for dry air and water vapor).  

For reference, taking L ≈ 2.5 × 10⁶ J kg⁻¹, c_p ≈ 1004 J kg⁻¹ K⁻¹, R_d ≈ 287 J kg⁻¹ K⁻¹, ε ≈ 0.622, and T ≈ 290 K often yields:

\[
   \Gamma_{s}
   \approx
   \Gamma_{d}\,
   \frac{\,1 + r \,\bigl(\tfrac{2.5\times10^6}{287\,\cdot\,290}\bigr)\,}
        {\,1 + r\,\bigl[\!0.622\,\tfrac{(2.5\times10^6)^2}{\,1004\,\cdot\,287\,\cdot\,290^2\,}\bigr]\,}\,.
\]

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2)  Mid-latitude moisture: r₀ = 5 g kg⁻¹
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

In the mid‐latitude scenario, near the surface we can take r ≈ 0.005 kg kg⁻¹ (5 g kg⁻¹).  Plugging in r = 0.005 at T ≈ 290 K gives a typical moist‐adiabatic lapse rate in the neighborhood of about 6–6.5 K km⁻¹.  A more precise calculation (using the above formula) often yields around:

\[
   \Gamma_{s}\bigl(\text{mid‐lats},\,r=0.005\bigr)
   \;\approx\;
   6.2\text{–}6.5\;\text{K km}^{-1}.
\]

Because the environmental lapse rate is

\[
   \Gamma_{\mathrm{env}} = 7 \;\text{K km}^{-1} \;>\; \Gamma_{s}\approx6.2\text{–}6.5\,,
\]

the atmosphere is (moist) unstable under near‐saturated lifting: a saturated parcel would cool at about 6–6.5 K km⁻¹ while the environment cools at 7 K km⁻¹, so the parcel ends up slightly warmer than its surroundings upon ascent.

a) Therefore, for r₀ = 5 g kg⁻¹ the troposphere is moist‐unstable (or at least conditionally unstable) under large‐scale lifting:  
\[
   \boxed{\text{Moist‐unstable for mid‐latitude moisture (}r_{0}=5\,\mathrm{g\,kg}^{-1}\text{).}}
\]

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3)  Tropical moisture: r₀ = 25 g kg⁻¹
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

In much more humid tropical conditions, near‐surface mixing ratios can reach 25 g kg⁻¹ (r ≈ 0.025 kg kg⁻¹).  Plugging in r = 0.025 at T ≈ 290 K yields an even smaller moist‐adiabatic lapse rate—often around 3–4 K km⁻¹.  A straightforward computation gives:

\[
   \Gamma_{s}\bigl(\text{tropics},\,r = 0.025\bigr)
   \;\approx\;
   3\text{–}4\;\text{K km}^{-1}.
\]

Hence,

\[
   \Gamma_{\mathrm{env}} = 7 \;\text{K\,km}^{-1}
   \;\gg\;
   \Gamma_{s}\approx3\text{–}4\;\text{K\,km}^{-1}.
\]

Thus, if the air is nearly saturated and lifted, it cools considerably more slowly (3–4 K km⁻¹) than the environmental 7 K km⁻¹, making it much warmer than its surroundings aloft.  This situation is strongly unstable and will favor deep convection.

b) Therefore, for r₀ = 25 g kg⁻¹ typical of the tropics, the troposphere is very moist‐unstable under large‐scale ascent:  
\[
   \boxed{\text{Strongly moist‐unstable for tropical moisture (}r_{0}=25\,\mathrm{g\,kg}^{-1}\text{).}}
\]

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Answer Summary
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
• (a)  Mid‐latitudes (r₀ = 5 g kg⁻¹):  The saturated lapse rate is roughly 6–6.5 K km⁻¹, so the environment (7 K km⁻¹) is slightly steeper → moist‐unstable.  
• (b)  Tropics (r₀ = 25 g kg⁻¹):  The saturated lapse rate can drop to ~3–4 K km⁻¹, making the troposphere strongly unstable to moist ascent.

question: As the sun's temperature decreases, its spectrum will move to longer wavelengths. Calculate the variation in Earth's equivalent blackbody temperature when the peak of the SW spectrum shifts from its existing position of $0.48 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ to a yellower wavelength of $0.55 \mu \mathrm{~m}$.
response:
Step-by-step solution:

We want to compare the Earth’s equilibrium (blackbody) temperature under two different solar “peak‐wavelength” conditions. The Sun’s total power output (its luminosity) is proportional to T_{\mathrm{sun}}^{4}, where T_{\mathrm{sun}} is the Sun’s effective temperature; however, for Earth’s blackbody temperature T_{\mathrm{E}}, the relevant scaling is essentially linear with T_{\mathrm{sun}} (provided that the Sun’s radius does not change), as shown below.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1) Relate solar temperature to peak wavelength via Wien’s law
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Wien’s displacement law states that the product of the peak wavelength λ_{\mathrm{max}} and the absolute temperature T_{\mathrm{sun}} is approximately constant:

λ_{\mathrm{max}} T_{\mathrm{sun}} = b,

where b ≈ 2.8978×10^{-3} m·K is Wien’s displacement constant. Thus,

T_{\mathrm{sun}} = b / λ_{\mathrm{max}}.

a) Original Sun temperature (λ_{\mathrm{max}} = 0.48 μm):

λ_{1} = 0.48×10^{-6} m.

T_{\mathrm{sun},1} = (2.8978×10^{-3}\,\mathrm{m\,K}) / (0.48×10^{-6}\,\mathrm{m}) 
≈ 6040 K.

b) New Sun temperature (λ_{\mathrm{max}} = 0.55 μm):

λ_{2} = 0.55×10^{-6} m.

T_{\mathrm{sun},2} = (2.8978×10^{-3}\,\mathrm{m\,K}) / (0.55×10^{-6}\,\mathrm{m}) 
≈ 5268 K.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2) Relate the change in Earth’s temperature to the change in Sun’s temperature
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Neglecting any change in the Sun’s radius and Earth–Sun distance, Earth’s effective temperature T_{\mathrm{E}} (in a simple blackbody balance) scales linearly with T_{\mathrm{sun}}, because:

• The Sun’s luminosity L_{\mathrm{sun}} ∝ R_{\mathrm{sun}}^{2} T_{\mathrm{sun}}^{4}.  
• At Earth (distance r), the flux S ∝ (L_{\mathrm{sun}} / 4π r^{2}).  
• Earth’s blackbody equilibrium temperature T_{\mathrm{E}} ∝ S^{1/4} and thus ∝ T_{\mathrm{sun}} (since R_{\mathrm{sun}} and r are taken as constants here).

Hence,  
T_{\mathrm{E},2} = T_{\mathrm{E},1} × (T_{\mathrm{sun},2} / T_{\mathrm{sun},1}).

If we take Earth’s “original” blackbody temperature T_{\mathrm{E},1} ≈ 255 K (a standard reference for Earth’s effective radiating temperature), then:

T_{\mathrm{E},2} = 255 K × (5268 K / 6040 K) ≈ 255 K × 0.872 ≈ 222 K.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3) Result: Variation in Earth’s blackbody temperature
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The shift in the Sun’s peak emission from 0.48 μm to 0.55 μm (i.e., a drop in T_{\mathrm{sun}} from about 6040 K to about 5268 K) would lower the Earth’s equilibrium blackbody temperature from about 255 K down to roughly 222 K.

Thus, the variation (the difference) is on the order of 33 K.

∴  
\boxed{ \text{Earth’s blackbody temperature decreases from about 255 K to about 222 K.} }

question: The Earth's orbital ellipticity causes it to be approximately $3.5 \%$ closer to the Sun in January compared to July. (a) Determine the resulting change in the Earth's equivalent blackbody temperature.
response:
Solution Explanation:

We wish to estimate how much the Earth’s effective (or “equivalent”) blackbody temperature changes from aphelion (in July) to perihelion (in January), knowing that Earth is about 3.5% closer to the Sun in January than in July.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1) Relating Earth–Sun Distance to Received Flux
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Since the solar flux F incident on Earth scales inversely with the square of the Earth–Sun distance R,

F ∝ 1/R²,

if January’s distance is 3.5% smaller than July’s, we denote  
R_jan = 0.965 × R_jul.  

Hence the ratio of the flux in January (perihelion) to that in July (aphelion) is  

F_jan / F_jul = (1 / R_jan²) ÷ (1 / R_jul²) 
               = (R_jul / R_jan)² 
               = (1 / 0.965)² 
               ≈ 1.0739.

Thus Earth receives about 7.39% more solar flux in January than in July.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2) Relating Flux to Blackbody Temperature
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Treating Earth as a blackbody radiator (a common approximation in simple climate–energy balance models), its equilibrium temperature T scales with the fourth root of the incident flux F:

T ∝ F^(1/4).

Therefore,

T_jan / T_jul = (F_jan / F_jul)^(1/4) = 1.0739^(1/4).

A convenient way to evaluate this is to note that for small x,  
(1 + x)^(1/4) ≈ 1 + x/4,  
but we can also compute it more exactly by taking logarithms:

• ln(1.0739) ≈ 0.0713  
• (1/4)×0.0713 ≈ 0.0178  
• exp(0.0178) ≈ 1.018  

Hence

T_jan / T_jul ≈ 1.018.

This implies that Earth’s effective blackbody temperature in January is about 1.8% higher than in July.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3) Numerical Difference in Blackbody Temperature
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

A standard reference value for Earth’s mean blackbody temperature is around  
T_⊕ ≈ 255 K.

Consequently, an increase of about 1.8% corresponds to

ΔT = 0.018 × 255 K ≈ 4.6 K.

Hence Earth’s effective blackbody temperature is roughly 4–5 K warmer at perihelion (January) than at aphelion (July).

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Final Answer
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

\[
\boxed{\text{The Earth's blackbody temperature is higher by about }4\text{–}5\,\mathrm{K}\text{ in January.}}
\]

question:
Examine a $250^{\circ} \mathrm{K}$ isothermal atmosphere with a single absorbing gas having a uniform mixing ratio of 0.05. The specific absorption cross section of this gas, depending on wavelength, is expressed as

$$
\sigma_{a \lambda}=1.0 e^{-\left(\frac{\lambda-\lambda_{0}}{\alpha}\right)^{2}} \mathrm{~m}^{2} \mathrm{~kg}^{-1},
$$

where $\lambda_{0}=0.5 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ and $\alpha=0.01 \mu \mathrm{~m}$. (a) Determine the optical path length as a function of $\lambda$ for radiation traveling downward from the top of the atmosphere to a height $z$.
response:
Solution Explanation:

We have a single absorbing gas, with uniform (constant) mixing ratio r = 0.05 (by mass), in an isothermal atmosphere of temperature T = 250 K. To find the optical path length (often called “optical depth”) τλ(z) for radiation traveling downward from the top of the atmosphere (z′ = ∞) to some height z, we use:

1) Definition of optical depth.  
   In the vertical (plane‐parallel) approximation, the optical depth from z to ∞ at wavelength λ is  
   τλ(z) = ∫(z to ∞) [σaλ · ρg(z′)] dz′,  
   where  
   • σaλ (m² kg⁻¹) is the (mass) absorption cross section at wavelength λ.  
   • ρg(z′) is the mass density of the absorbing gas at altitude z′.  

2) Uniform mixing ratio.  
   Because the mixing ratio by mass is constant at r = 0.05, the mass density of the absorbing gas is  
   ρg(z′) = 0.05 × ρair(z′).  
   Here, ρair(z′) is the total air density at z′.

3) Isothermal atmosphere.  
   For an isothermal atmosphere of temperature T, the total pressure p(z) decreases exponentially with a scale height H,  
   p(z) = p(0) e^(−z/H),  
   where p(0) is (for example) the surface pressure, and H = (R T) / g for a suitably chosen gas constant R and gravitational acceleration g.  

   The total air density ρair(z) then also decays exponentially because  
   ρair(z) = p(z) / (R′ T)  ∝  e^(−z/H).  

4) Column‐integrated mass of the gas.  
   The integral of ρair from z to ∞ is proportional to e^(−z/H).  Specifically,  
   ∫(z to ∞) ρair(z′) dz′ = ρair(z) · H.  
   Equivalently, in terms of pressure, the column mass of air from z to ∞ is p(z)/g, and since the gas is 5 % by mass (r = 0.05), the column mass of the absorber is 0.05 × [p(z)/g].

5) Putting it all together.  
   Since σaλ does not depend on altitude (only on wavelength), we factor out σaλ and find  
   τλ(z) = ∫(z to ∞) σaλ [0.05 × ρair(z′)] dz′  
          = 0.05 σaλ ∫(z to ∞) ρair(z′) dz′.  
   Using the hydrostatic relation for column mass,  
   ∫(z to ∞) ρair(z′) dz′ = p(z)/(g),  
   we obtain  
   τλ(z) = 0.05 σaλ [p(z)/g].  

   If the pressure at altitude z is p(z) = p(0) e^(−z/H), then  
   τλ(z) = 0.05 σaλ [p(0)/g] e^(−z/H).  

Because the question only asks for the optical depth from the top down to height z (rather than from z to the surface), it is conventional to write τλ(z) in a form using p(0) (often the surface pressure denoted pₛ) and the exponential factor e^(−z/H).

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Answer:

a) The optical path length (optical depth) from the top of the atmosphere (z′ = ∞) down to height z at wavelength λ is  
\[
\boxed{
\tau_\lambda(z) \;=\; 0.05 \;\sigma_{a \lambda}\;\frac{p(0)}{g}\;e^{-\,\frac{z}{H}}
}
\]

question: Venus exhibits an albedo of 0.77 and is positioned at an average distance from the sun of $1.110^{11} \mathrm{~m}$. (a) Determine the equivalent blackbody temperature of Venus.
response:
Step-by-Step Solution:

We wish to find the equivalent blackbody temperature of Venus given:
• Albedo α = 0.77.  
• Distance from the Sun r = 1.10×10^11 m.  
• Solar luminosity L_sun = 3.828×10^26 W (often used in such calculations).  
• Stefan-Boltzmann constant σ = 5.670374419×10^−8 W m^−2 K^−4.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------
a) Equivalent Blackbody Temperature

1) Solar flux at Venus.  
   The total luminosity of the Sun spreads out spherically, giving a flux S at distance r:  
   S = L_sun / (4πr²).

   Numerically, one often uses the known “solar constant” near Earth (≈1361 W/m² at r_Earth ≈ 1.496×10^11 m) and then rescales to the distance of Venus. However, we can also compute it directly:

   S = 3.828 × 10^26 W  
       ---------------------------------  
       4π (1.10 × 10^11 m)²  

   (But for brevity, many like to ratio to the Earth’s flux. Either method yields a flux of approximately S ≈ 2520 W/m² at Venus’s orbital distance.)

2) Fraction of solar flux absorbed.  
   Venus’s bond albedo is α = 0.77, meaning 77% of incoming light is reflected, and only 23% is absorbed.  
   Absorbed flux per unit area of Venus (facing the Sun):  
   (1 – α) S = (1 – 0.77)(2520 W/m²) = 0.23 × 2520 ≈ 580 W/m².

3) Distribute over the entire surface.  
   The planet radiates approximately like a sphere, so the absorbed flux must be divided over 4× the cross-sectional area:  
   F = 580 W/m² ÷ 4 = 145 W/m²,

   which is the effective flux that is reradiated thermally (assuming no greenhouse effect for this simple blackbody calculation).

4) Stefan-Boltzmann relation.  
   The planet’s effective blackbody temperature T satisfies:  
   σ T⁴ = F,  
   or  
   T = (F / σ)^(1/4).

   Plugging in F = 145 W/m²,

   T = [145 W/m² / (5.670374419 × 10^−8 W m^−2 K^−4)]^(1/4).  

   Numerically, one finds T ≈ 225 K.

Therefore, the resulting equivalent blackbody temperature of Venus (neglecting its thick atmosphere and greenhouse effects) is:

a) \(\boxed{225 \text{ K (approximately)}}\).

question: Examine an isothermal atmosphere that is significantly opaque to LW radiation. (a) What proportion of the LW radiance emitted at a zenith angle of zero comes from the topmost 3 optical depths? (b) Calculate the range of altitudes, expressed in scale heights, that is covered by the layer with optical depths ranging from 0.1 to 3.0 in an isothermal setting.
response:
Solution Explanation:

We consider a plane‐parallel, isothermal atmosphere in LTE (local thermodynamic equilibrium) emitting longwave (LW) radiation. The problem is posed for radiation propagating vertically upward (zenith angle θ = 0). Under these assumptions, the monochromatic radiance emergent at the top is given (schematically) by integrating the local emission weighted by the transmission to the top of the atmosphere. For an isothermal atmosphere, the source function may be treated as constant (B(T)) and the formal solution simplifies considerably.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
a) Fraction of LW radiance from the topmost 3 optical depths
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

1) Emergent intensity.  
   In an isothermal layer of total optical thickness τtot ≫ 1, the emergent intensity I at the top can be approximated by  
   I ≈ ∫(from τ=0 to τ=∞) B(T) e^(−τ) dτ = B(T) ∫(0 to ∞) e^(−τ) dτ = B(T).  
   Here we have made use of τtot ≫ 1 so that effectively the upper boundary sees an infinite column.

2) Fraction from the topmost Δτ.  
   More precisely, the fraction of the emergent radiance contributed by the optical‐depth interval from τ = 0 to τ = 3 is  
   f = [ ∫(0 to 3) e^(−τ) dτ ] / [ ∫(0 to ∞) e^(−τ) dτ ].  

3) Perform the integrals.  
   Numerator: ∫(0 to 3) e^(−τ) dτ = 1 − e^(−3).  
   Denominator: ∫(0 to ∞) e^(−τ) dτ = 1.  

4) Final fraction.  
   Therefore,  
   f = 1 − e^(−3) ≈ 1 − 0.0498 ≈ 0.95  
   i.e., about 95% of the LW emission at zenith angle zero emerges from the topmost 3 optical depths.

Hence,  
a) \(\boxed{0.95 \;\text{(approximately)}}\)

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
b) Range of altitudes (in scale heights) for τ from 0.1 to 3.0
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

1) Optical depth profile in an isothermal atmosphere.  
   Let z measure height from the ground upward. Define τ(z) as the optical depth measured from the top (z → ∞) down to height z. In an isothermal atmosphere with scale height H, the density ρ(z) ~ e^(−z/H), and one finds
